analyzed: iti tatra api samastasya khalu sāmnaḥ upāsanam sādhu
translated: ), there also, because of the statement, 'Verily, the meditation on the entire Sāman is good' (Chānd.

original: 'iti ca pañcavidhasya' chā / / /
analyzed: iti ca pañcavidhasya chā  /
translated: ), 'and on the fivefold' (Chānd.

original: 'atha saptavidhasya' chā / / /
analyzed: atha saptavidhasya chā
translated: ), 'and on the sevenfold' (Chānd.

original: iti ca sāmna eva upāsyatva upakramāt tasmin eva ādityādi adhyāsaḥ /🔽etasmāt eva ca sāmna upāsyatva avagamāt 'pṛthivī hiṅkāraḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: iti ca sāmnaḥ eva upāsya tva upakramāt tasmin eva ādityādi adhyāsaḥ  etasmāt eva ca sāmna upāsya tva avagamāt pṛthivī hiṅkāraḥ chā
translated: ), the superimposition of the sun and so on is on the Sāman itself, which is to be meditated upon, because of the introduction.🔽And because of the understanding that the Sāman is to be meditated upon, even when there is a reversal of the direction beginning with 'The earth is the syllable Hiṃ;' (Chānd.

original: ityādinirdeśaviparyaye api hiṅkārādiṣu eva pṛthivyādi dṛṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: ityādi nirdeśa viparyaye api hiṅkāra ādiṣu eva pṛthivī ādi dṛṣṭiḥ
translated: ), the vision of the earth and so on is in the syllable 'Hiṃ' and so on.

original: tasmāt anaṅgāśrayā ādityādimatayaḥ aṅgeṣu udgīthādiṣu kṣipyeran iti siddham // //
analyzed: tasmāt anaṅga āśrayāḥ āditya ādi matayaḥ aṅgeṣu udgītha ādiṣu kṣipyeran iti siddham  /
translated: Therefore, it is established that the thoughts of the sun and so on, which have as their substratum what is not a part of the sacrifice, should be transferred to the parts, the Udgītha and so on.

original: āsīna adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: āsīna adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on sitting. Sūtra.

original: āsīnaḥ saṃbhavāt / / / /
analyzed: āsīnaḥ saṃbhavāt
translated: One should sit while meditating, because of the origin.

original: karmāṅgasaṃbaddheṣu tāvat upāsaneṣu karmatantratvāt na āsanādicintā na api samyak darśane vastutantratvāt vijñānasya /
analyzed: karma aṅga saṃbaddheṣu tāvat upāsaneṣu karma tantra tvāt na āsana ādi cintā na api samyak darśane vastu tantra tvāt vijñānasya
translated: In meditations connected with the limbs of action, there is no consideration of posture etc. because of the dependence on action, nor in the true vision, because of the dependence on the thing, of knowledge.

original: itareṣu tu upāsaneṣu kim aniyamena tiṣṭhan āsīnaḥ śayāno vā pravarteta uta niyamena āsīna eva iti cintayati /
analyzed: itareṣu tu upāsaneṣu kim aniyamena tiṣṭhan āsīnaḥ śayānaḥ vā pravarteta uta niyamena āsīnaḥ eva iti cintayati
translated: But in other meditations, should one engage while standing, sitting, or lying down, without restriction, or necessarily only while sitting? He thinks.

original: tatra mānasatvāt upāsanasya aniyamaḥ śarīrasthiteḥ iti /
analyzed: tatra mānasa tvāt upāsanasya aniyamaḥ śarīra sthiteḥ iti
translated: There, because meditation is mental, there is no restriction on the posture of the body.

original: evaṃ prāpte bravīti āsīna eva upāsīta iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte bravīti āsīnaḥ eva upāsīta iti
translated: When this is the case, he says one should meditate only while sitting.

original: kutaḥ saṃbhavāt /
analyzed: kutas saṃbhavāt
translated: Why? Because of the origin.

original: upāsanaṃ nāma samānapratyayapravāhakaraṇaṃ na ca tat gacchato dhāvato vā saṃbhavati gatyādīnāṃ cittavikṣepakatvāt /
analyzed: upāsanam nāma samāna pratyaya pravāha karaṇam na ca tat gacchataḥ dhāvataḥ vā saṃbhavati gati ādīnām citta vikṣepaka tvāt
translated: Meditation is the production of a stream of similar ideas, and that is not possible for one who is going or running, because going etc. distract the mind.

original: tiṣṭhataḥ api dehadhāraṇe vyāpṛtaṃ mano na sūkṣmavastunirīkṣaṇakṣamaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tiṣṭhataḥ api deha dhāraṇe vyāpṛtam manaḥ na sūkṣma vastu nirīkṣaṇa kṣamam bhavati
translated: Even for one who is standing, the mind engaged in supporting the body is not capable of examining a subtle object.

original: śayānasya api akasmāt eva nidrayā abhibhūyeta /
analyzed: śayānasya api akasmāt eva nidrayā abhibhūyeta
translated: Even for one who is lying down, he might suddenly be overcome by sleep.

original: āsīnasya tu evañjātīyako bhūyān doṣaḥ suparihara iti saṃbhavati tasya upāsanam // //
analyzed: āsīnasya tu evañjātīyakaḥ bhūyān doṣaḥ supariharaḥ iti saṃbhavati tasya upāsanam  /
translated: But for one who is sitting, such a great fault is easily avoided, so meditation is possible for him.

original: dhyānāc ca / / / /
analyzed: dhyānāt ca
translated: And from meditation.

original: api ca dhyāyati arthaṃ eṣa yat samānapratyayapravāhakaraṇam /
analyzed: api ca dhyāyati artham eṣa yat samāna pratyaya pravāha karaṇam
translated: Moreover, meditation is the act of keeping the mind fixed on one object.

original: dhyāyatiḥ ca praśithila aṅgaceṣṭeṣu pratiṣṭhitadṛṣṭiṣu ekaviṣaya ākṣiptacitteṣu upacaryamāṇo dṛśyate dhyāyati bako dhyāyati proṣitabandhuḥ
analyzed: dhyāyatiḥ ca praśithila aṅga ceṣṭeṣu pratiṣṭhita dṛṣṭiṣu eka viṣaya ākṣipta citteṣu upacaryamāṇaḥ dṛśyate dhyāyati bakaḥ dhyāyati proṣita bandhuḥ
translated: And meditation is seen to be used figuratively for those whose limbs and movements are relaxed, whose eyes are fixed, and whose minds are absorbed in one object, as in 'the crane meditates', 'one whose relative is away meditates'.

original: āsīnaḥ ca anāyāso bhavati /
analyzed: āsīnaḥ ca anāyāsaḥ bhavati
translated: And sitting is free from exertion.

original: tasmāt api āsīnakarma upāsanam // //
analyzed: tasmāt api āsīnakarma upāsanam  /
translated: Therefore, meditation is also the action of one who is sitting.

original: acalatvaṃ cāpekṣya / / / /
analyzed: acala tvam ca apekṣya
translated: And it is based on immobility.

original: api ca 'dhyāyatīva pṛthivī' chā / / /
analyzed: api ca dhyāyati iva pṛthivī chā
translated: Moreover, 'the earth meditates' (Ch. Up. 7.6.1).

original: iti atra pṛthivyādiṣu acalatvameva apekṣya dhyāyativādo bhavati tat ca liṅgam upāsanasya āsīnakarmatve // //
analyzed: iti atra pṛthivī ādiṣu acala tvam eva apekṣya dhyāyati vādaḥ bhavati tat ca liṅgam upāsanasya āsīna karma tve  /
translated: Here, the statement about meditation is based only on immobility in the earth and so on. And that is an indication that meditation is the action of one who is sitting.

original: smaranti ca / / / /
analyzed: smaranti ca
translated: And the cultured remember.

original: smaranti api ca śiṣṭā upāsana aṅgatvena āsanam 'śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiramāsanamātmanaḥ' gī / / ityādinā /
analyzed: smaranti api ca śiṣṭā upāsana aṅgatvena āsanam śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiram āsanam ātmanaḥ ityādinā
translated: And the cultured remember sitting as an accessory of meditation, as in 'Having placed one's own firm seat in a pure place' (Gita 6.11).

original: ata eva padmakādīnām āsanaviśeṣāṇām upadeśo yogaśāstre // //
analyzed: atas eva padmaka ādīnām āsana viśeṣāṇām upadeśaḥ yoga śāstre
translated: For this very reason, the teaching of special postures such as the lotus posture is in the Yoga scriptures.

original: ekāgratā adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: ekāgratā adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on one-pointedness. Sutra.

original: yatraikāgratā tatrāviśeṣāt / / / /
analyzed: yatra ekāgra tā tatra aviśeṣāt
translated: Where there is one-pointedness, there it is, because there is no distinction.

original: dik deśakāleṣu saṃśayaḥ kim asti kaścit niyamo na asti vā iti /
analyzed: diś deśa kāleṣu saṃśayaḥ kim asti kaścid niyamaḥ na asti vā iti
translated: There is doubt regarding direction, place and time - is there any restriction or not?

original: prāyeṇa vaidikeṣu ārambheṣu digādiniyamadarśanāt syāt iha api kaścit niyama iti yasya matiḥ taṃ prati āha dik deśakāleṣu arthalakṣaṇa eva niyamaḥ
analyzed: prāyeṇa vaidikeṣu ārambheṣu diś ādi niyama darśanāt syāt iha api kaścid niyamaḥ iti yasya matiḥ tam prati āha diś deśa kāleṣu artha lakṣaṇaḥ eva niyamaḥ
translated: Since in most Vedic undertakings a restriction regarding direction etc. is seen, one who thinks that there may be some restriction here also, for him it is said: Regarding direction, place and time, the restriction is only based on the purpose.

original: yatra eva asya diśi deśe kāle vā manasaḥ sokaryeṇa ekāgratā bhavati tatra eva upāsīta prācīdik pūrvāhna prācīna pravaṇādivat viśeṣa aśrāvaṇāt
analyzed: yatra eva asya diśi deśe kāle vā manasaḥ sokaryeṇa ekāgra tā bhavati tatra eva upāsīta prācīdik pūrvāhna prācīna pravaṇādivat viśeṣa aśrāvaṇāt
translated: One should worship only in that direction, place or time where his mind becomes concentrated through the act of meditation, like the eastern direction, forenoon, or a place sloping towards the east. Because no particularity is mentioned.

original: ekāgratayā iṣṭāyāḥ sarvatra aviśeṣāt /
analyzed: ekāgra tayā iṣṭāyāḥ sarvatra aviśeṣāt
translated: Because the desired concentration is not distinguished anywhere.

original: nanu viśeṣam api kecit āmananti 'same śucau kharkarāvahnivālukāvivarjite śabdajalāśrayādibhiḥ /
analyzed: nanu viśeṣam api kecid āmananti same śucau kharkarā vahni vālukā vivarjite śabda jala āśraya ādibhiḥ
translated: But some mention a particularity also: 'On an even, clean place, free from pebbles, ash and sand, free from sound, water, trees etc.,

original: manonukūle natu cakṣupīḍane guhānivātāśrayaṇe prayojayet' śve / /
analyzed: manaḥ nukūle na tu cakṣu pīḍane guhā nivāta āśrayaṇe prayojayet śve
translated: pleasing to the mind, but not painful to the eyes, one should resort to a cave or a sheltered place.' (SvetUp. 1.11)

original: iti yathā iti /🔽ucyate satyam asti evañjātīyako niyamaḥ /
analyzed: iti yathā iti  ucyate satyam asti evañjātīyakaḥ niyamaḥ
translated: As it is said.🔽It is said: True, there is a restriction of this kind.

original: sati tu etasmin tadgateṣu viśeṣaniyama iti suhṛt bhūtvā ācārya ācaṣṭe /
analyzed: sati tu etasmin tadgateṣu viśeṣa niyamaḥ iti suhṛd bhūtvā ācāryaḥ ācaṣṭe
translated: But when this is present, the restriction regarding particularities is stated by the teacher, being a well-wisher.

original: 'manonukūle' iti ca eṣā śrutiḥ yatra ekāgratā tatra eva iti etat eva darśayati // //
analyzed: manonukūle iti ca eṣā śrutiḥ yatra ekāgra tā tatra eva iti etat eva darśayati  /
translated: And the Vedic text, 'agreeable to the mind', shows that it is just where there is one-pointedness that this (concentration) is to be practised.

original: āprāyaṇa adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: āprāyaṇa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on (the necessity of) repetition till the end of life.

original: ā prayāṇāt tatrāpi hi dṛṣṭam / / / /
analyzed: ā prayāṇāt tatra api hi dṛṣṭam  /
translated: (The repetition of the meditation) is to be performed till the end of life; for it is seen even then.

original: āvṛttiḥ sarva upāsaneṣu ādartavya iti sthitam ādye adhikaraṇe /
analyzed: āvṛttiḥ sarva upāsaneṣu ādartavya iti sthitam ādye adhikaraṇe
translated: It has been established in the first section that repetition is to be observed in all meditations.

original: tatra yāni tāvat samyak darśanārthāni upāsanāni tāni avaghātādivat kāryaparyavasānāni iti jñātameva eṣām āvṛttiparimāṇam /
analyzed: tatra yāni tāvat samyak darśana arthāni upāsanāni tāni avaghāta ādi vat kārya paryavasānāni iti jñātam eva eṣām āvṛtti parimāṇam
translated: Of those, the extent of the repetition of those meditations which are for the purpose of perfect knowledge is already known to be the same as that of the threshing (of corn) and other (rites), i.e., to end with the completion of the result (of the rite).

original: na hi samyak darśane kārye niṣpanne yatnāntaraṃ kiñcit śāsituṃ śakyam /
analyzed: na hi samyak darśane kārye niṣpanne yatna antaram kiñcid śāsitum śakyam
translated: For when the result, perfect knowledge, has been accomplished, it is not possible to enjoin any further effort.

original: aniyojyabrahmātmatvapratipatteḥ śāstrasya aviṣayatvāt /
analyzed: a niyojya brahma ātmatva pratipatteḥ śāstrasya aviṣaya tvāt
translated: Because when one has attained the knowledge that Brahman is one's own self, which cannot be enjoined (by the Veda), the Veda has no scope (for further activity).

original: yāni punaḥ abhyudayaphalāni teṣu eṣā cintā kiṃ kiyantañcit kālaṃ pratyayam āvartya uparamet uta yāvajjīvam āvartayet iti /
analyzed: yāni punar abhyudaya phalāni teṣu eṣā cintā kim kiyantañcid kālam pratyayam āvartya uparamet uta yāvajjīvam āvartayet iti
translated: Now, with regard to those (meditations) which have prosperity for their result, there arises the question whether one should cease (from the repetition of the meditation) after repeating the meditation for a certain time, or whether he should repeat it as long as he lives.

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptam /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: kiyantañcit kālaṃ pratyayam abhyasya utsṛjet āvṛttiviśiṣṭasya upāsanaśabdārthasya kṛtatvāt iti /
analyzed: kiyantañcid kālam pratyayam abhyasya utsṛjet āvṛtti viśiṣṭasya upāsana śabda arthasya kṛta tvāt iti
translated: One should cease after practising the meditation for a certain time, because the meaning of the word 'upāsana' (meditation) with the affix 'vishiṣṭa' (which signifies repetition) has been accomplished.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ āprāyaṇāt eva āvartayet pratyayam /🔽antyapratyayavaśāt adṛṣṭaphalaprāpteḥ /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ āprāyaṇāt eva āvartayet pratyayam  antya pratyaya vaśāt adṛṣṭa phala prāpteḥ
translated: To this we reply: The soul must return to life even after the final dissolution of the body, because the result of the act is not yet experienced.

original: karmāṇi api hi janmāntara upabhogyaṃ phalam ārabhamāṇāni tat anurūpaṃ bhāvanāvijñānaṃ prāyaṇakāla ākṣipanti /🔽'savijñāno bhavati savijñānamevānvavakrāmati' 'yaccittastenaiṣa prāṇamāyāti /
analyzed: karmāṇi api hi janmāntara upabhogyam phalam ārabhamāṇāni tat anurūpam bhāvanā vijñānam prāyaṇa kāle ākṣipanti  sa vijñānaḥ bhavati sa vijñānam eva anvavakrāmati yat cittaḥ tena eṣa prāṇam āyāti
translated: For the acts, when beginning to produce a result to be experienced in a future birth, throw into the final moment of consciousness a corresponding impression.

original: prāṇastejasā yuktaḥ sahātmanā yathāsaṃkalpitaṃ lokaṃ nayati' iti ca evamādiśrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ tejasā yuktaḥ saha ātmanā yathā saṃkalpitam lokam nayati iti ca evamādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: This is shown by such passages as, He becomes possessed of consciousness, and follows after consciousness; what his mind is intent on, that he becomes on the dissolution of the body; the prāṇa united with heat carries the soul to the world it has earned according to its thoughts Bṛ Up , , ; , 0,

original: tṛṇajalūkānidarśanāt ca /
analyzed: tṛṇa jalūkā nidarśanāt ca
translated: and by the comparison of the soul with a frog Bṛ Up , , 0

original: pratyayāḥ tu ete svarūpa anuvṛttiṃ muktvā kim anyat prāyaṇakālabhāvi bhāvanāvijñānam apekṣeran /
analyzed: pratyayāḥ tu ete svarūpa anuvṛttim muktvā kim anyat prāyaṇa kāla bhāvi bhāvanā vijñānam apekṣeran
translated: But what other reason can the impressions have to require the impression of the final moment of consciousness, if not the fact of their continuing to exist in their own nature?

original: tasmāt ye pratipattavyaphalabhāvanātmakāḥ pratyayaḥ teṣu aprāyaṇāt āvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt ye pratipattavya phala bhāvanā ātmakāḥ pratyayaḥ teṣu a prāyaṇāt āvṛttiḥ
translated: Therefore those impressions which are of the nature of acts to be accomplished must return to life even after the final dissolution of the body.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ 'sa yāvatkraturayamasmāllokātpraiti' iti prāyaṇakāle api pratyaya anuvṛttiṃ darśayati /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ sa yāvat kratuḥ ayam asmāt lokāt praiti iti prāyaṇa kāle api pratyaya anuvṛttim darśayati
translated: And so the Śruti also declares, As far as his will extends, he goes from this world Śve Up ,

original: smṛtiḥ api 'yaṃ yaṃ vāpi smaranbhāvaṃ tyajatyante kalevaram /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ api yam yam vā api smaran bhāvam tyajati ante kalevaram
translated: The Smṛti also says: ‘Whatever state one remembers at the time of death, to that he attains by constant practice’ (Gītā 8.6).

original: taṃ tamevaiti kaunteya sadā tadbhāvabhāvitaḥ' gī / /
analyzed: tam tam eva eti kaunteya sadā tad bhāva bhāvitaḥ
translated: Smṛti also says: ‘Whatever state of being a man remembers when he leaves this body, to that he goes, O son of Kunti, being always made such by his thought’ (Gītā, 8.6).

original: iti 'prayāṇakāle manasācalena' gī / / iti ca /
analyzed: iti prayāṇa kāle manasā acalena iti ca
translated: And: ‘At the time of death, with an unwavering mind’ (Gītā, 8.7).

original: 'so 'ntavelāyāmetattrayaṃ pratipadyeta' iti ca maraṇavelāyām api kartavyaśeṣaṃ śrāvayati // //
analyzed: saḥ nta velāyām etat trayam pratipadyeta iti ca maraṇa velāyām api kartavya śeṣam śrāvayati  /
translated: And: ‘At the time of death, he should adopt these three’ (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad, 3.2.8), it declares that even at the time of death, there is a remainder of duties to be performed.

original: tat adhigama adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: tat adhigama adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Now begins the section on the attainment of Brahman.

original: tadadhigama uttarapūrvāghayor aśleṣavināśau tadvyapadeśāt / / / /
analyzed: tad adhigame uttara pūrva aghayoḥ aśleṣa vināśau tad vyapadeśāt
translated: The non-adhesion and destruction of the past and future sins of one who has attained Brahman are declared by the scriptures.

original: gataḥ tṛtīyaśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: gataḥ tṛtīya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of the third section is finished.

original: atha idānīṃ brahmavidyāphalaṃ prati cintā pratāyate /
analyzed: atha idānīm brahma vidyā phalam prati cintā pratāyate
translated: Now the discussion begins regarding the fruit of the knowledge of Brahman.

original: brahma adhigame sati tat viparītaphalaṃ duritaṃ kṣīyate na kṣīyate vā iti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: brahma adhigame sati tat viparīta phalam duritam kṣīyate na kṣīyate vā iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: When Brahman is attained, the sin which is the opposite of that, is it destroyed or not? This is the doubt.

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptam /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: phalārthatvāt karmaṇaḥ phalam adatvā na saṃbhāvyate kṣayaḥ /
analyzed: phala artha tvāt karmaṇaḥ phalam a da tvā na saṃbhāvyate kṣayaḥ
translated: Since the action is for the sake of the fruit, it is not possible for it to be destroyed without giving its fruit.

original: phaladāyinī hi asya śaktiḥ śrutyā samadhigatā /
analyzed: phala dāyinī hi asya śaktiḥ śrutyā samadhigatā
translated: For its power to give the fruit has been understood from the scriptures.

original: yadi tadantareṇa eva phala upabhogam apavṛjyeta śrutiḥ kadarthitā syāt /
analyzed: yadi tad antareṇa eva phala upabhogam apavṛjyeta śrutiḥ kadarthitā syāt
translated: If one were to be liberated without experiencing the fruit, the scriptures would be contradicted.

original: smaranti ca 'nahi karma kṣīyate' iti /
analyzed: smaranti ca nahi karma kṣīyate iti
translated: And they remember (the text), 'For the action does not perish.'

original: nanu evaṃ sati prāyaścitta upadeśaḥanarthakaḥ prāpnoti /
analyzed: nanu evam sati prāyaścitta upadeśaḥ anarthakaḥ prāpnoti
translated: But if it is so, the teaching of expiatory rites would be meaningless.

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: prāyaścittānāṃ naimittikatva upapatteḥ gṛhadāha iṣṭyādivat /
analyzed: prāyaścittānām naimittika tve upapatteḥ gṛha dāhaḥ iṣṭi ādi vat
translated: Because it is proper that expiatory rites are occasional, like the Iṣṭi for burning the house.

original: api ca prāyaścittānāṃ doṣasaṃyogena vidānāt bhavet api doṣakṣapaṇārthatā na tu evaṃ brahmavidyāyāṃ vidhānam asti /
analyzed: api ca prāyaścittānām doṣa saṃyogena vidānāt bhavet api doṣa kṣapaṇa artha tā na tu evam brahma vidyāyām vidhānam asti
translated: Moreover, because expiatory rites are enjoined in connection with faults, they may indeed serve to destroy the faults, but there is no such injunction in the case of the knowledge of Brahman.

original: nanu anabhyupagamyamāne brahmavidaḥ karmakṣaye tatphalasya avaśyaṃ bhoktavyatāvāt anirmokṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: nanu an abhyupagamyamāne brahma vidaḥ karma kṣaye tad phalasya avaśyam bhoktavya tāvāt anirmokṣaḥ syāt
translated: But if the destruction of the fruits of action by one who knows Brahman is not accepted, then there would be no liberation, because those fruits must necessarily be experienced.

original: na iti ucyate /
analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: It is said: No.

original: deśakālanimittāpekṣo mokṣaḥ karmaphalavat bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: deśa kāla nimitta apekṣaḥ mokṣaḥ karma phala vat bhaviṣyati
translated: Like the fruits of action, liberation will depend on place, time, and occasion.

original: tasmāt na brahma adhigame duritanivṛttiḥ iti /
analyzed: tasmāt na brahma adhigame duritanivṛttiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no cessation of sin upon the realization of Brahman.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ tat adhigame brahma adhigame sati uttarapūrvayoḥ aghayoḥ aśleṣavināśau bhavataḥ uttarasya aśleṣaḥ pūrvasya vināśaḥ /🔽kasmāt /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ tat adhigame brahma adhigame sati uttara pūrvayoḥ aghayoḥ aśleṣa vināśau bhavataḥ uttarasya aśleṣaḥ pūrvasya vināśaḥ  kasmāt
translated: When this has been reached, we say that when Brahman is realized, the two sins, the later and the earlier, are not connected and are destroyed, the later one is not connected and the earlier one is destroyed.🔽Why?

original: tat vyapadeśāt /
analyzed: tad vyapadeśāt
translated: Because of that designation.

original: tathā hi brahmavidyā prakriyāyāṃ saṃbhāvyamānasaṃbandhasya āgāmino duritasya anabhisaṃbandhaṃ🔽viduṣo vyapadiśati 'yathā puṣkarapalāśa āpo na śliṣyanta evamevaṃvidi pāpaṃ karma
analyzed: tathā hi brahma vidyā prakriyāyām saṃbhāvyamāna saṃbandhasya āgāminaḥ duritasya an abhisaṃbandham  viduṣaḥ vyapadiśati yathā puṣkarapalāśe āpaḥ na śliṣyante evam evaṃvidi pāpam karma
translated: For in the process of the knowledge of Brahman, it declares the non-connection of the sin that is possible to be connected with the future,

original: na śliṣyate' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: na śliṣyate iti
translated: with the knower: 'Just as water does not stick to a lotus leaf, so evil deeds do not stick to one who knows thus.'

original: tathā vināśam api pūrva ucitasya duritasya vyapadiśati 'tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaivaṃ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante' chā / 🔽iti /
analyzed: tathā vināśam api pūrvaḥ ucitasya duritasya vyapadiśati tat yathā iṣīkā tūlam agnau protam pradūyeta evam ha asya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante chā  / iti
translated: Similarly, it declares the destruction of the sin that is proper before: 'Just as a piece of cotton wool thrown into fire would be consumed, so all his evil deeds would be consumed.'

original: ayam aparaḥ karmakṣayavyapadeśo bhavati 'bhidyate hṛdayagranthiśchidyante sarvasaṃśayāḥ /
analyzed: ayam aparaḥ karma kṣaya vyapadeśaḥ bhavati bhidyate hṛdaya granthiḥ chidyante sarva saṃśayāḥ
translated: This is another declaration of the destruction of karma: 'The knot of the heart is split, all doubts are cut off,

original: kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇi tasmindṛṣṭe parāvare' mu / / / iti /
analyzed: kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi tasmin dṛṣṭe parāvare iti
translated: and his evil deeds are destroyed, when the highest Brahman is seen.'

original: yat uktam anupabhuktaphalasya karmaṇaḥ kṣayakalpanāyāṃ śāstraṃ kadarthitaṃ syāt iti /
analyzed: yat uktam anupabhukta phalasya karmaṇaḥ kṣaya kalpanāyām śāstram kadarthitam syāt iti
translated: What was said - that if the destruction of karma whose fruit has not been experienced is imagined, the scripture would be tortured -

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: that is not a fault.

original: na hi vayaṃ karmaṇaḥ phaladāyinīṃ śaktim avajānīmahe /
analyzed: na hi vayam karmaṇaḥ phala dāyinīm śaktim avajānīmahe
translated: For we do not deny the power of karma to give fruit.

original: vidyata eva sā /
analyzed: vidyate eva sā
translated: That exists.

original: sā tu vidyādinā kāraṇāntareṇa pratibadhyata iti vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: sā tu vidyā ādinā kāraṇa antareṇa pratibadhyate iti vadāmaḥ
translated: But we say that that (knowledge) is obstructed by another cause, such as knowledge.

original: śaktisadbhāvamātre ca śāstraṃ vyāpriyate na pratibandha apratibandhayoḥ api /
analyzed: śakti sadbhāva mātre ca śāstram vyāpriyate na pratibandha apratibandhayoḥ api
translated: And the scripture applies only to the mere existence of the power, not to obstruction or non-obstruction.

original: na hi karma kṣīyata iti etat api smaraṇam autsargikaṃ na bhogāt ṛte karma kṣīyata tadarthatvāt iti /
analyzed: na hi karma kṣīyate iti etat api smaraṇam autsargikam na bhogāt ṛte karma kṣīyata tad artha tvāt iti
translated: For this remembrance (that the scripture is not contradicted by the fact that the results of actions are not always experienced) is not a general rule: An action is not exhausted except through experience, because that is the purpose of the action.

original: iṣyata eva tu prāyaścittādinā tasya kṣayaḥ 'sarvaṃ pāpmānaṃ tarati' 'tarati brahmahatyāṃ yo 'śvamedhena yajate ya u cainameva vada' ityādi
analyzed: iṣyate eva tu prāyaścitta ādinā tasya kṣayaḥ sarvam pāpmānam tarati tarati brahmahatyām yaḥ u śvamedhena yajate yaḥ u ca enam eva vade ityādi
translated: But the destruction of that (action) by penance etc. is indeed accepted: He overcomes all evil, He who performs the horse sacrifice overcomes even the killing of a Brahmin, and he who speaks of it, etc.

original: yat tu uktaṃ naimittikāni prāyaścittāni bhaviṣyanti iti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam naimittikāni prāyaścittāni bhaviṣyanti iti
translated: But it has been said that penances will be occasional.

original: tat asat /
analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

original: doṣasaṃyogena codyamānānām eṣāṃ doṣanirghātaphalasaṃbhave phalāntarakalpanā anupapatteḥ /
analyzed: doṣa saṃyogena codyamānānām eṣām doṣa nirghāta phala saṃbhave phala antara kalpanā anupapatteḥ
translated: For when these (penances) are enjoined in connection with faults, if the result of the destruction of the faults is possible, it is not proper to assume another result.

original: yatpunaḥ etat uktaṃ na prāyaścittavat doṣakṣaya uddeśena vidyāvidānam asti iti /
analyzed: yat punar etat uktam na prāyaścitta vat doṣa kṣaya uddeśena vidyā vidānam asti iti
translated: And as for what was said: There is no knowledge of the destruction of faults with the purpose of penance, like penance,

original: atra brūmaḥ saguṇāsu tāvat vidyāsu vidyata eva vidhānam /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ saguṇāsu tāvat vidyāsu vidyate eva vidhānam
translated: we say this: In the knowledge with qualities, the injunction certainly exists.

original: tāsu ca vākyaśeṣa aiśvaryaprāptiḥ pāpanivṛttiḥ ca vidyāvata ucyate /
analyzed: tāsu ca vākyaśeṣa aiśvarya prāptiḥ pāpa nivṛttiḥ ca vidyāvataḥ ucyate
translated: And in those (passages), the attainment of lordship and the cessation of sin are stated as the fruits of the knowledge of Brahman.

original: tayoḥ ca avivakṣākāraṇaṃ na asti iti ataḥ pāpmaprahāṇapūrvaka aiśvaryaprāptiḥ tāsāṃ phalam iti niścīyate /
analyzed: tayoḥ ca avivakṣā kāraṇam na asti iti atas pāpma prahāṇa pūrvaka aiśvarya prāptiḥ tāsām phalam iti niścīyate
translated: And there is no reason for not intending those (attainment of lordship and cessation of sin), therefore it is ascertained that the fruit of those (passages) is the attainment of lordship preceded by the cessation of sin.

original: nirguṇāyāṃ tu vidyāyāṃ yadi api vidhānaṃ na asti tathā api akartṛ ātmatvabodhāt karmapradāhasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: nirguṇāyām tu vidyāyām yadi api vidhānam na asti tathā api akartṛ ātma tva bodhāt karma pradāha siddhiḥ
translated: But in the knowledge of Brahman without qualities, even though there is no injunction, still, due to the realization of the Self as not an agent, the burning up of the (fruits of) actions is established.

original: aśleṣa iti ca āgāmiṣu karmasu kartṛtvameva na pratipadyate brahmavit iti darśayati /
analyzed: aśleṣaḥ iti ca āgāmiṣu karmasu kartṛ tvam eva na pratipadyate brahma vid iti darśayati
translated: And the (text) without attachment shows that one who knows Brahman does not undertake agency with regard to future actions.

original: atikrānteṣu tu yadi api mithyājñānāt kartṛtvaṃ pratipeda iva tathā api vidyāsāmarthyāt mithyājñānanivṛtteḥ tāni api pravilīyanta iti āha vināśa 🔽iti /
analyzed: atikrānteṣu tu yadi api mithyājñānāt kartṛ tvam pratipeda iva tathā api vidyā sāmarthyāt mithyājñāna nivṛtteḥ tāni api pravilīyante iti āha vināśa  iti
translated: But with regard to past actions, even though one may have undertaken agency due to false knowledge, still, due to the power of knowledge, with the cessation of false knowledge, those (actions) also dissolve away. Thus it is said: dissolution (of the fruits of past actions).

original: pūrvasiddhakartṛtva bhoktṛtva viparītaṃ hi triṣu api kāleṣu akartṛtva abhoktṛtvasvarūpaṃ
analyzed: pūrva siddha kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva viparītam hi triṣu api kāleṣu akartṛ tva abhoktṛ tva svarūpam
translated: For the nature of Brahman is the opposite of the agency and enjoyership that were previously established. In all three times (past, present, and future), it is the nature of non-agency and non-enjoyership.

original: brahma aham asmi na itaḥ pūrvam api kartā bhoktā vā aham āsaṃ na idānīṃ na api bhaviṣyatkāla
analyzed: brahma aham asmi na itas pūrvam api kartā bhoktā vā aham āsam na idānīm na api bhaviṣyat kāla
translated: I am Brahman. I was not an agent or enjoyer even before this, nor am I now, nor will I be in the future.

original: iti brahmavit avagacchati /
analyzed: iti brahma vid avagacchati
translated: Thus the knower of Brahman understands.

original: evam eva ca mokṣa upapadyate /
analyzed: evam eva ca mokṣaḥ upapadyate
translated: And in this way alone is liberation possible.

original: anyathā hi anādikālapravṛttānāṃ karmāṇāṃ kṣayābhāve mokṣa abhāvaḥ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā hi anādi kāla pravṛttānām karmāṇām kṣaya abhāve mokṣa abhāvaḥ syāt
translated: For otherwise, if there were no destruction of the actions that have been going on since beginningless time, there would be no liberation.

original: na ca deśakālanimittāpekṣo mokṣaḥ karmaphalavat bhavitum arhati /
analyzed: na ca deśa kāla nimitta apekṣaḥ mokṣaḥ karma phala vat bhavitum arhati
translated: And liberation cannot be like the fruit of action, dependent on place, time, and cause.

original: anityatva prasaṅgāt /
analyzed: anitya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to the undesirable consequence of impermanence.

original: parokṣatva anupapatteḥ ca jñānaphalam /
analyzed: parokṣa tva anupapatteḥ ca jñānaphalam
translated: And because it is not possible for the fruit of knowledge to be imperceptible.

original: tasmāt brahma adhigame duritakṣaya iti sthiram // //
analyzed: tasmāt brahma adhigame duritakṣaya iti sthiram  /
translated: Therefore it is certain that on the attainment of Brahman, sin is destroyed.

original: itara asaṃśleṣa adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: itara asaṃśleṣa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the non-admixture of the other. Sūtra.

original: itarasyāpy evam asaṃśleṣaḥ pāte tu / / / /🔽pūrvasmin adhikaraṇe bandhahetoḥ aghasya svābhāvikasya aśleṣavināśau jñānanimittau śāstravyapadeśāt nirūpitau /
analyzed: itarasya api evam asaṃśleṣaḥ pāte tu  pūrvasmin adhikaraṇe bandha hetoḥ aghasya svābhāvikasya aśleṣa vināśau jñāna nimittau śāstra vyapadeśāt nirūpitau
translated: The non-admixture of the other also is like this. But in the case of falling, there is destruction.🔽In the previous section, the destruction of sin, which is the cause of bondage and is natural, and its non-admixture, were determined to be caused by knowledge, on the basis of scriptural statements.

original: dharmasya punaḥ śāstrīyatvāt śāstrīyeṇa jñānena avirodha iti āśaṅkya tat nirākaraṇāya pūrva adhikaraṇanyāya atideśaḥ kriyate /
analyzed: dharmasya punar śāstrīya tvāt śāstrīyeṇa jñānena avirodha iti āśaṅkya tad nirākaraṇāya pūrva adhikaraṇanyāya atideśaḥ kriyate
translated: But since merit is prescribed by the scriptures, it is feared that there is no contradiction with knowledge prescribed by the scriptures. To refute that, the reasoning of the previous section is extended.

original: itarasya api puṇyasya karmaṇa evam aghavat asaṃśleṣo vināśaḥ ca jñānavato bhavataḥ /
analyzed: itarasya api puṇyasya karmaṇaḥ evam aghavat asaṃśleṣaḥ vināśaḥ ca jñānavataḥ bhavataḥ
translated: For the other also, for meritorious action, there is non-admixture and destruction like sin, for one who has knowledge.

original: kutaḥ tasya api svaphalahetutvena jñānaphalapratibandhitvaprasaṅgāt /🔽'ubhe u haivaiṣa ete tarati' bṛ / / /
analyzed: kutas tasya api sva phala hetu tvena jñāna phala pratibandhi tva prasaṅgāt  ubhe u ha eva eṣa ete tarati bṛ
translated: Why? Because in that case also, it would follow that it is an obstruction to the fruit of knowledge, since it is the cause of its own fruit.

original: ityādiśrutiṣu ca duṣkṛtavat sukṛtasya api praṇāśavyapadeśāt /🔽akartṛ ātmatvabodhanimittasya ca karmakṣayasya sukṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ tulyatvāt 'kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇi' mu / / /
analyzed: ityādi śrutiṣu ca duṣkṛta vat sukṛtasya api praṇāśa vyapadeśāt  akartṛ ātma tva bodha nimittasya ca karma kṣayasya sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ tulya tvāt kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi
translated: And in the scriptures such as He indeed crosses over both (Brhadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.22), merit is declared to be destroyed in the same way as demerit.

original: iti ca aviśeṣaśruteḥ /
analyzed: iti ca a viśeṣa śruteḥ
translated: And the destruction of karma, which is the cause of the realization of the self as non-agent, is the same for both good and bad actions. And the scripture says without distinction: His actions are destroyed (Katha Upanishad 2.2.9).

original: yatra api kevala eva pāpmaśabdo dṛśyate tatra api tena eva puṇyam api akalitam iti draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: yatra api kevalaḥ eva pāpma śabdaḥ dṛśyate tatra api tena eva puṇyam api akalitam iti draṣṭavyam
translated: Where the word 'sin' is seen alone, there also it should be understood that merit is included by that word.

original: jñānaphala apekṣayā nikṛṣṭaphalatvāt /
analyzed: jñāna phala apekṣayā nikṛṣṭa phala tvāt
translated: Because it has a lower fruit in comparison to the fruit of knowledge.

original: asti ca śrutau puṇye api pāpmaśabdaḥ 'nainaṃ setumahorātre tarataḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: asti ca śrutau puṇye api pāpma śabdaḥ na enam setum ahar rātre tarataḥ chā
translated: And in the scriptures, the word 'sin' is used for merit also: Neither day nor night can cross over this bridge (Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.6).

original: iti atra saha duṣkṛtena sakṛtamapi anukramya sarve pāpmānaḥ ato nivartanta iti aviśeṣeṇa eva prakṛte puṇye pāpmaśabdaprayogāt /
analyzed: iti atra saha duṣkṛtena sakṛtam api anukramya sarve pāpmānaḥ atas nivartante iti aviśeṣeṇa eva prakṛte puṇye pāpma śabda prayogāt
translated: Here, even merit along with demerit is enumerated, and all sins turn away from it. Thus the word 'sin' is used without distinction even for the merit that is being discussed.

original: pāte tu iti tu śabdaḥ avadhāraṇārthaḥ /
analyzed: pāte tu iti tu śabdaḥ avadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: But in the case of falling, the word 'but' has the meaning of restriction.

original: evaṃ dharma adharmayoḥ bandhahetvoḥ vidyāsāmarthyāt aśleṣavināśasiddheḥ avaśyaṃbhāvinī viduṣaḥ śarīrapāte muktiḥ iti avadhārayati // //
analyzed: evam dharma adharmayoḥ bandha hetvoḥ vidyā sāmarthyāt aśleṣa vināśa siddheḥ avaśyaṃbhāvinī viduṣaḥ śarīrapāte muktiḥ iti avadhārayati  /
translated: Thus, by the power of knowledge, the non-adhesion and destruction of dharma and adharma, which are the causes of bondage, are established. Therefore, it is ascertained that liberation is inevitable for the knower at the fall of the body.

original: anārabdha adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: anārabdha adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the non-commencement of results. Sutra.

original: anārabdhakārye eva tu pūrve tadavadheḥ / / / /
analyzed: anārabdha kārye eva tu pūrve tad avadheḥ
translated: But the former ones, whose results have not commenced, are destroyed by the knowledge of Brahman.

original: pūrvayoḥ adhikaraṇayoḥ jñānanimittaḥ sukṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ vināśaḥ avadhāritaḥ sa kim
analyzed: pūrvayoḥ adhikaraṇayoḥ jñāna nimittaḥ sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ vināśaḥ avadhāritaḥ sa kim
translated: In the two previous sections, it has been determined that the destruction of good and bad actions is caused by knowledge. Is that destruction

original: aviśeṣeṇa ārabdhakāryayoḥ anārabdhakāryayoḥ ca bhavati uta viśeṣeṇa anārabdhakāryayoḥ eva iti vicāryate /🔽'tatra ubhe u haivaiṣa ete tarati' bṛ / / /
analyzed: aviśeṣeṇa ārabdha kāryayoḥ anārabdhakāryayoḥ ca bhavati uta viśeṣeṇa anārabdha kāryayoḥ eva iti vicāryate  tatra ubhe u ha eva eṣa ete tarati
translated: without distinction, of those whose results have commenced and those whose results have not commenced, or with distinction, only of those whose results have not commenced? This is being considered.

original: iti evamādiśrutiṣu aviśeṣaśravaṇāt aviśeṣeṇa eva kṣaya iti /
analyzed: iti evamādi śrutiṣu aviśeṣa śravaṇāt aviśeṣeṇa eva kṣayaḥ iti
translated: In the Upanishads, such as He indeed crosses over both, there is the statement without distinction, so the destruction is without distinction.

original: evaṃ prāpte pratyāha anārabdhakārye eva tu iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte pratyāha anārabdha kārye eva tu iti
translated: When this is the prima facie view, he replies: But the former ones, whose results have not commenced.

original: apravṛttaphale eva pūrve janmāntarasaṃcite asmin api ca janmani prāk jñāna utpatteḥ
analyzed: apravṛtta phale eva pūrve janma antara saṃcite asmin api ca janmani prāk jñāna utpatteḥ
translated: Those accumulated in previous births, whose results have not commenced, and even in this birth, before the arising of knowledge,

original: saṃcite sukṛtaduṣkṛte jñāna adhigamāt kṣīyete na tu ārabdhakārye sāmibhuktaphale
analyzed: saṃcite sukṛta duṣkṛte jñāna adhigamāt kṣīyete na tu ārabdha kārye sāmibhukta phale
translated: When knowledge is attained, the accumulated good and bad actions are destroyed, but not those whose results have begun or whose results have been experienced.

original: yābhyām etat brahmajñāna āyatanaṃ janma nirmitam /
analyzed: yābhyām etat brahma jñāna āyatanam janma nirmitam
translated: By which two [actions], this body, the abode of the knowledge of Brahman, is created.

original: kuta etat 'tasya tāvadeva ciraṃ yāvanna vimokṣye 'tha saṃpatsye' chā / / /
analyzed: kutas etat tasya tāvat eva ciram yāvat na vimokṣye saṃpatsye
translated: Where is this stated? In the section beginning with For him it is a long time only until he is released, then he will attain. (ChU 3.14.1)

original: iti śarīrapātau adhikaraṇāt kṣemaprāpteḥ /
analyzed: iti śarīrapātau adhikaraṇāt kṣema prāpteḥ
translated: Because of the attainment of peace upon the fall of the body.

original: itarathā hi jñānāt aśeṣakarmakṣaye sati sthitihetu abhāvāt jñānaprāpti anantarameva kṣemamśnu avīta /
analyzed: itarathā hi jñānāt aśeṣa karma kṣaye sati sthiti hetu abhāvāt jñāna prāpti anantaram eva kṣemam śnu avīta
translated: For otherwise, if all actions were destroyed by knowledge, and there were no cause for continued existence, then immediately after the attainment of knowledge one would attain peace.

original: tatra śarīrapātapratīkṣāṃ na ācakṣīta /
analyzed: tatra śarīrapāta pratīkṣām na ācakṣīta
translated: In that case, one would not speak of waiting for the fall of the body.

original: nanu vastubalena eva ayam akartṛ ātmāvabodhaḥ karmāṇi kṣapayan kathaṃ kānicit kṣapayet kānicit ca upekṣeta /
analyzed: nanu vastu balena eva ayam akartṛ ātma avabodhaḥ karmāṇi kṣapayan katham kānicid kṣapayet kānicid ca upekṣeta
translated: But how can this knowledge of the self as non-agent, which destroys actions by the power of reality, destroy some and ignore others?

original: na hi samāne agnibījasaṃparke keṣāñcit bījaśaktiḥ kṣīyate keṣāñcit na kṣīyata iti śakyam aṅgīkartum iti /
analyzed: na hi samāne agni bīja saṃparke keṣāñcid bīja śaktiḥ kṣīyate keṣāñcid na kṣīyate iti śakyam aṅgīkartum iti
translated: For it is not possible to accept that when there is contact with fire and seed, the potency of some seeds is destroyed and that of others is not destroyed.

original: ucyate na tāvat anāśritya ārabdhakāryaṃ karmāśayaṃ jñāna utpattiḥ upapadyate /
analyzed: ucyate na tāvat an āśritya ārabdhakāryam karmāśayam jñāna utpattiḥ upapadyate
translated: It is said: First of all, the arising of knowledge is not possible without depending on the store of actions whose results have begun.

original: āśrite ca tasmin kulālacakravat pravṛttavegasya antarāle pratibandha asaṃbhavāt bhavati vegakṣayapratipālanam /
analyzed: āśrite ca tasmin kulāla cakra vat pravṛtta vegasya antarāle pratibandha asaṃbhavāt bhavati vega kṣaya pratipālanam
translated: And when that (soul) has entered (the body), the exhaustion of the force (of the past actions) is preserved, because there is no possibility of an obstruction in the interval of one whose momentum has begun, like a potter's wheel.

original: akartṛ ātmabodhaḥ api hi mithyājñānabādhanena karmāṇi ucchinatti /
analyzed: akartṛ ātma bodhaḥ api hi mithyājñāna bādhanena karmāṇi ucchinatti
translated: And the knowledge of the Self as not the agent also destroys the actions by removing the false knowledge.

original: bādhitam api tu mithyājñānaṃ dvicandrajñānavat saṃskāravaśāt kañcitkālam anuvartata eva /
analyzed: bādhitam api tu mithyājñānam dvi candra jñāna vat saṃskāra vaśāt kañcid kālam anuvartate eva
translated: But the false knowledge, even though removed, continues for some time by the force of the impressions, just like the knowledge of two moons.

original: api ca na eva atra vivaditavyaṃ brahmavidā kañcitkālaṃ śarīraṃ dhriyate na vā dhriyata iti /
analyzed: api ca na eva atra vivaditavyam brahma vidā kañcitkālam śarīram dhriyate na vā dhriyate iti
translated: Moreover, there should be no dispute here as to whether the knower of Brahman sustains the body for some time or not.

original: kathaṃ hi ekasya svahṛdayapratyayaṃ brahmavedanaṃ dehadhāraṇaṃ ca apareṇa pratikṣeptuṃ śakyeta /
analyzed: katham hi ekasya sva hṛdaya pratyayam brahma vedanam deha dhāraṇam ca apareṇa pratikṣeptum śakyeta
translated: For how can another refute what is known in one's own heart, namely, the knowledge of Brahman and the sustaining of the body?

original: śrutismṛtiṣu ca sthitaprajñalakṣaṇanirdeśena etadeva nirucyate /
analyzed: śruti smṛtiṣu ca sthita prajña lakṣaṇa nirdeśena etat eva nirucyate
translated: And this is stated by the description of the characteristics of one whose mind is steady in the scriptures and Smritis.

original: tasmāt anārabdhakāryayoḥ eva sukṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ vidyāsāmarthyāt kṣaya iti nirṇayaḥ // //🔽agnihotrādi adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: tasmāt anārabdha kāryayoḥ eva sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ vidyā sāmarthyāt kṣayaḥ iti nirṇayaḥ  / agnihotra ādi adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Therefore, the conclusion is that the good and bad actions whose effects have not begun are destroyed by the power of knowledge.🔽The section on the Agnihotra and other rituals. Sutra.

original: agnihotrādi tu tatkāryāyaiva taddarśanāt / / / /
analyzed: agnihotra ādi tu tad kāryāya eva tad darśanāt
translated: But the Agnihotra and other (rituals) are only for that purpose, because that is seen.

original: puṇyasya api aśleṣavināśayoḥ aghanyāyaḥ atidiṣṭaḥ saḥ atideśaḥ sarvapuṇyaviṣaya iti āśaṅkya prativakti agnihotrādi tu iti /
analyzed: puṇyasya api aśleṣa vināśayoḥ agha nyāyaḥ atidiṣṭaḥ saḥ atideśaḥ sarva puṇya viṣayaḥ iti āśaṅkya prativakti agnihotra ādi tu iti
translated: The rule about sin in regard to the non-adherence and destruction of merit has been extended. That extension is in regard to all merit, this is the doubt. He replies: But the Agnihotra etc.

original: tu śabda āśaṅkām upanudati /
analyzed: tu śabdaḥ āśaṅkām upanudati
translated: The word 'but' removes the doubt.

original: yat nityaṃ karma vaidikam agnihotrādi tat tat kāryāya eva bhavati /
analyzed: yat nityam karma vaidikam agnihotra ādi tat tat kāryāya eva bhavati
translated: That which is the eternal Vedic rite, the Agnihotra etc., that is only for its own purpose.

original: jñānasya yatkāryaṃ tadeva asya api kāryam ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: jñānasya yat kāryam tat eva asya api kāryam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the purpose of this also is the same as the purpose of knowledge.

original: kutaḥ 'tametaṃ vedānuvacanena brāhmaṇā vividiṣanti yajñena dānena' bṛ / / /
analyzed: kutas tam etam veda anuvacanena brāhmaṇāḥ vividiṣanti yajñena dānena
translated: From where? 'The Brahmins desire to know Him through the recitation of the Vedas, through sacrifice, through giving' (Br.

original: ityādidarśanāt /
analyzed: ityādi darśanāt
translated: This is seen etc.

original: nanu jñānakarmaṇoḥ vilakṣaṇakāryatvāt kārya ekatva anupapattiḥ /
analyzed: nanu jñāna karmaṇoḥ vilakṣaṇa kāryatvāt kārya ekatva anupapattiḥ
translated: But since the effects of knowledge and action are different, it is not possible for them to have the same effect.

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: jvaramaraṇakāryayoḥ api dadhiviṣayoḥ guḍamantrasaṃyuktayoḥ tṛptipuṣṭikāryadarśanāt /
analyzed: jvara maraṇa kāryayoḥ api dadhi viṣayoḥ guḍa mantra saṃyuktayoḥ tṛpti puṣṭi kārya darśanāt
translated: Because even curd and poison, which have the effects of fever and death, when combined with jaggery and mantras, are seen to have the effects of nourishment and satisfaction.

original: tadvat karmaṇaḥ api jñānasaṃyuktasya mokṣakārya upapatteḥ /
analyzed: tadvat karmaṇaḥ api jñāna saṃyuktasya mokṣa kārya upapatteḥ
translated: In the same way, it is possible for action also, when combined with knowledge, to have the effect of liberation.

original: nanu anārabhyo mokṣaḥ katham asya karmakāryatvam ucyate /
analyzed: nanu anārabhyaḥ mokṣaḥ katham asya karma kārya tvam ucyate
translated: But liberation is not a beginningless effect. How can it be said to be the effect of action?

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: ārāt upakārakatvāt karmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: ārāt upakāraka tvāt karmaṇaḥ
translated: Because action helps from a distance.

original: jñānasya eva hi prāpakaṃ satkarma prāṇāḍyā mokṣakāraṇam iti upacaryate /
analyzed: jñānasya eva hi prāpakam sat karma prāṇāḍyā mokṣa kāraṇam iti upacaryate
translated: For action, which is the means of attaining knowledge, is figuratively spoken of as the cause of release through the susumna.

original: ata eva ca atikrāntaviṣayam etat kārya ekatva abhidhānam /
analyzed: atas eva ca atikrānta viṣayam etat kārya ekatva abhidhānam
translated: And for this very reason this statement of the oneness of the effect refers to something past.

original: na hi brahmavida āgāmi agnihotrādi saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na hi brahma vidaḥ āgāmi agnihotra ādi saṃbhavati
translated: For the Agnihotra, etc. to be performed in the future is not possible for one who knows Brahman.

original: aniyojyabrahmātmatva pratipatteḥ śāstrasya aviṣayatvāt /
analyzed: a niyojya brahma ātmatva pratipatteḥ śāstrasya aviṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the realization of one's identity with Brahman, which is not to be enjoined, is not the subject of the scriptures.

original: saguṇāsu tu vidyāsu kartṛtva anativṛtteḥ saṃbhavati āgāmi api agnihotrādi /
analyzed: saguṇāsu tu vidyāsu kartṛ tva anativṛtteḥ saṃbhavati āgāmi api agnihotrādi
translated: But in the vidyas with attributes, the Agnihotra, etc. to be performed in the future are possible, because the knower has not transcended his state of being an agent.

original: tasya api nirabhisaṃdhinaḥ kāryāntara abhāvāt vidyāsaṃgati upapattiḥ // //
analyzed: tasya api nirabhisaṃdhinaḥ kāryāntara abhāvāt vidyāsaṃgati upapattiḥ  /
translated: And for him, who has no ulterior motive, it is proper to connect it with the vidya, because there is no other effect.🔽But with regard to what does this statement about the destruction of non-adhesion refer? Or with regard to what does this statement about the application of the Agnihotra, etc. to be performed in the future by some reciters refer?

original: kiṃviṣayaṃ punaḥ idam aśleṣavināśa vacanaṃ kiṃviṣayaṃ vā ado viniyogavacanam ekeṣāṃ śākhinām 'tasya putrā dāyamupayanti suhṛdaḥ sādhukṛtyāṃ
analyzed: kiṃviṣayam punar idam aśleṣa vināśa vacanam kiṃviṣayam vā adaḥ viniyoga vacanam ekeṣām śākhinām tasya putrāḥ dāyam upayanti suhṛdaḥ sādhu kṛtyām
translated: 'His sons take his wealth, his friends his good deeds,

original: dviṣantaḥ pāpakṛtyām' iti /
analyzed: dviṣantaḥ pāpa kṛtyām iti
translated: his enemies his evil deeds.'

original: ata uttaraṃ paṭhati
analyzed: atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: Therefore he recites the following answer:

original: ato 'nyāpi hy ekeṣām ubhayoḥ / / / /
analyzed: atas nya api hi ekeṣām ubhayoḥ  /
translated: For others, it is both.

original: ataḥ agnihotrādeḥ nityātkarmaṇaḥ anyāpi hi asti sādhukṛtyā yā phalam abhisaṃdhāya kriyate tasyā eṣa viniyoga ukta ekeṣāṃ śākhinām 'suhṛdaḥ 🔽sādhukṛtyāmupayanti' iti /
analyzed: atas agnihotra ādeḥ nityāt karmaṇaḥ anyā api hi asti sādhu kṛtyā yā phalam abhisaṃdhāya kriyate tasyāḥ eṣa viniyogaḥ uktaḥ ekeṣām śākhinām suhṛdaḥ  / sādhu kṛtyām upayanti iti
translated: Hence, there is also another kind of good action, besides the obligatory actions such as the Agnihotra, which is performed with a view to a certain fruit. To that kind of good action the passage quoted above from the Śākhā of some refers, The friends enter upon the good action.

original: tasyā eva ca idam aghavat aśleṣavināśanirūpaṇam itarasya api evam aśleṣa iti /
analyzed: tasyāḥ eva ca idam agha vat aśleṣa vināśa nirūpaṇam itarasya api evam aśleṣaḥ iti
translated: And to that kind of good action only the passage about the destruction of the sin of contact belongs; the other kind of good action also is not affected by contact.

original: tathā jātīyakasya kāmyasya karmaṇo vidyāṃ prati anupakārakatve saṃpratipattiḥ ubhayoḥ api jaiminibādarāyaṇayoḥ ācāryayoḥ // //
analyzed: tathā jātīyakasya kāmyasya karmaṇaḥ vidyām prati anupakāraka tve saṃpratipattiḥ ubhayoḥ api jaimini bādarāyaṇayoḥ ācāryayoḥ  /
translated: And both teachers, Jaimini and Bādarāyaṇa, agree in maintaining that the good action of the kind mentioned does not assist the knowledge of Brahman.

original: vidyājñānasādhana adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: vidyā jñāna sādhana adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the means of knowledge and the means of attaining knowledge.

original: yad eva vidyayeti hi / / / /🔽samadhigatam etat anantara adhikaraṇe nityam agnihotrādikaṃ karma mumukṣuṇā mokṣaprayojana🔽uddeśena kṛtam upāttaduritakṣayahetutvadvāreṇa sattvaśuddhikāraṇatāṃ pratipadyamānaṃ
analyzed: yat eva vidyayā iti hi  samadhigatam etat anantara adhikaraṇe nityam agnihotra ādikam karma mumukṣuṇā mokṣa prayojana  uddeśena kṛtam upātta durita kṣaya hetu tva dvāreṇa sattva śuddhi kāraṇa tām pratipadyamānam
translated: For it is said that it is knowledge alone which is the means of attaining Brahman.

original: mokṣaprayojanabrahma adhigamanimittatvena brahmavidyayā saha ekakāryaṃ bhavati iti /
translated: It has been ascertained in the preceding adhikaraṇa that the obligatory action such as the Agnihotra, which a man who is desirous of final release must perform with the view of attaining final release, becomes the means of purifying the internal organ by destroying the sin which has been committed, and thus becomes the cause of the purification of the internal organ, and that thus it is connected with the knowledge of Brahman as the means of attaining Brahman, and has the same effect as the knowledge of Brahman.

original: tatra agnihotrādi karmāṅgavyapāśrayavidyāsaṃyuktaṃ kevalaṃ ca asti /
analyzed: tatra agnihotra ādi karma aṅga vyapāśraya vidyā saṃyuktam kevalam ca asti
translated: There are the rites such as the Agnihotra, which are connected with the knowledge that has for its substratum the parts of the sacrificial action, and which are also unaccompanied by that knowledge.

original: 'ya evaṃ vidvānayajati' 'ya evaṃ vidvāñjuhoti' 'ya evaṃ vidvāñchaṃsati' 'ya evaṃ vidvāngāyati' 'tasmādevaṃvidameva brahmāṇaṃ kurviti nānevaṃ 🔽vidaṃ' chā / / /
analyzed: yaḥ evam vidvān a yajati yaḥ evam vidvān juhoti yaḥ evam vidvān śaṃsati yaḥ evam vidvān gāyati tasmāt evaṃvidam eva brahmāṇam kuru iti na anevam  vidam chā
translated: For there are such passages as the following: 'He who knowing thus sacrifices,' 'He who knowing thus offers oblations,' 'He who knowing thus sings,' 'He who knowing thus chants,' 'Therefore one should appoint as the Brahman priest only him who knows this, not him who does not know this' (Chānd. 3.17.7);

original: 'tenobhau kuruto yaścaitadevaṃ veda yaśca na veda' chā / / /🔽ityādivacanebhyo vidyāsaṃyuktam asti kevalam api asti /🔽tatra idaṃ vicāryate kiṃ vidyāsaṃyuktameva agnihotrādikaṃ karma mumukṣoḥ vidyāhetutvena
analyzed: tena ubhau kurutaḥ yaḥ ca etat evam veda yaḥ ca na veda chā  ityādi vacanebhyaḥ vidyā saṃyuktam asti kevalam api asti  tatra idam vicāryate  kim vidyā saṃyuktam eva agnihotra ādikam karma mumukṣoḥ vidyā hetu tvena
translated: 'By it both of them perform, he who knows this and he who does not know this' (Chānd. 3.14.1).🔽From such passages it follows that there are rites such as the Agnihotra which are connected with knowledge and which are also unaccompanied by that knowledge.

original: tayā saha ekakāryatvaṃ pratipadyate na kevalam uta vidyāsaṃyuktaṃ kevalaṃ ca aviśeṣeṇa iti /
analyzed: tayā saha eka kārya tvam pratipadyate na kevalam uta vidyā saṃyuktam kevalam ca aviśeṣeṇa iti
translated: Now, with regard to this, the following question is to be considered: Is it only the rite of Agnihotra, etc. which is connected with knowledge that becomes the cause of knowledge for one who is desirous of final release, and which, therefore, along with that knowledge, attains the same end, and not the rite which is unaccompanied by knowledge? Or is it that whether it is accompanied by knowledge or not, it is equally a means of knowledge?

original: kutaḥ saṃśayaḥ 'tametamātmānaṃ yajñena vividiṣanti' iti yajñādīnāmvi aśeṣeṇa ātmavedanāṅgatvena śravaṇāt /
analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ tam etam ātmānam yajñena vividiṣanti iti yajña ādīnām vi aśeṣeṇa ātma vedanā aṅga tvena śravaṇāt
translated: From what is the doubt? Because the rites such as the Agnihotra are heard as being the means of knowing the Self in their entirety.

original: vidyāsaṃyuktasya ca agnihotrādīnām aviśeṣatva avagamāt /
analyzed: vidyā saṃyuktasya ca agnihotra ādīnām aviśeṣa tva avagamāt
translated: And because it is understood that the rites such as the Agnihotra, when accompanied by knowledge, are not different from those which are unaccompanied by knowledge.

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptaṃ vidyāsaṃyuktam eva karmāgnihotrādi ātmavidyāśeṣatvaṃ pratipadyate na vidyāhīnam /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam vidyā saṃyuktam eva karma agnihotra ādi ātma vidyā śeṣa tvam pratipadyate na vidyā hīnam
translated: What is the prima facie view? Only the rites such as Agnihotra, etc. when associated with knowledge become the means to the knowledge of the Self, not those devoid of knowledge.

original: vidyā upetasya viśiṣṭatva avagamāt vidyāvihīnāt /
analyzed: vidyā upetasya viśiṣṭa tva avagamāt vidyāvihīnāt
translated: Because it is understood that the rites associated with knowledge are superior to those devoid of knowledge.

original: 'yadahareva juhoti tadahaḥ punarmṛtyumapajayatyevaṃvidvān' ityādiśrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: yat ahar eva juhoti tat ahar punarmṛtyum apajayati evaṃvidvān ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: From such Vedic texts as, 'The man who knows thus conquers death day after day' (Ch. 4.1.2).

original: 'buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi' gī / /
analyzed: buddhyā yuktaḥ yayā pārtha karma bandham prahāsyasi
translated: 'United with wisdom, O Partha, you will cast off the bondage of actions' (Gita 4.39).

original: 'dūreṇa hyavaraṃ karma buddhiyogāddhanañjaya' gī / /
analyzed: dūreṇa hi avaram karma buddhi yogāt hanañjaya
translated: 'For action far excels inaction, O Dhananjaya' (Gita 3.8).

original: ityādismṛtibhya ca iti /
analyzed: ityādi smṛtibhya ca iti
translated: And from such Smriti texts as these.

original: evaṃ prāpte pratipadyate yadeva vidyayā iti hi /
analyzed: evam prāpte pratipadyate yat eva vidyayā iti hi
translated: When this is the prima facie view, the author replies: 'For, indeed, it is only knowledge, etc.'

original: satyam etat /
analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

original: vidyāsaṃyuktaṃ karmāgnihotrādikaṃ vidyāvihīnāt karmaṇaḥ agnihotrāt viśiṣṭaṃ vidvāniva brāhmaṇo vidyāvihīnāt brāhmaṇāt /
analyzed: vidyā saṃyuktam karma agnihotra ādikam vidyā vihīnāt karmaṇaḥ agnihotrāt viśiṣṭam vidvān iva brāhmaṇaḥ vidyā vihīnāt brāhmaṇāt
translated: The rites such as Agnihotra, etc. when associated with knowledge are superior to the rites such as Agnihotra, etc. devoid of knowledge, just as a learned Brahmin is superior to an unlearned Brahmin.

original: tathā api na atyantam anapekṣaṃ vidyāvihīnaṃ karmāgnihotrādikam /
analyzed: tathā api na atyantam anapekṣam vidyā vihīnam karma agnihotra ādikam
translated: However, the rites such as Agnihotra, etc. devoid of knowledge are not absolutely useless.

original: kasmāt 'tametamātmānaṃ yajñena vividiṣanti' iti aviśeṣeṇa agnihotrādeḥ vidyāhetutvena śrutatvāt /
analyzed: kasmāt tam etam ātmānam yajñena vividiṣanti iti aviśeṣeṇa agnihotra ādeḥ vidyā hetu tvena śruta tvāt
translated: Why? Because the Agnihotra and so on are heard as the cause of knowledge without distinction, as in the statement, 'By sacrifice they seek to know that Self.'

original: nanu vidyāsaṃyuktasya agnihotrādeḥ vidyāvihīnāt viśiṣṭatva avagamāt vidyāvihīnam agnihotrādi ātmavidyāhetutvena anapekṣameva iti yuktam /
analyzed: nanu vidyā saṃyuktasya agnihotra ādeḥ vidyā vihīnāt viśiṣṭa tva avagamāt vidyā vihīnam agnihotra ādi ātma vidyā hetutvena anapekṣam eva iti yuktam
translated: But since it is understood that the Agnihotra and so on, when united with knowledge, are superior to those without knowledge, it is proper to consider that the Agnihotra and so on without knowledge are irrelevant as the cause of knowledge of the Self.

original: na etat evam /
analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

original: vidyāsahāyasya agnihotrādeḥ vidyānimittena sāmarthya atiśayena yogāt ātmajñānaṃ prati kaścit kāraṇa atiśayo bhaviṣyati na tathā vidyāvihīnasya 🔽iti yuktaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: vidyā sahāyasya agnihotra ādeḥ vidyā nimittena sāmarthya atiśayena yogāt ātma jñānam prati kaścid kāraṇa atiśayaḥ bhaviṣyati na tathā vidyā vihīnasya  iti yuktam kalpayitum
translated: It is proper to suppose that the Agnihotra and so on, when accompanied by knowledge, will have some superiority as a cause of knowledge of the Self, because of their connection with the excess of ability due to the cause of knowledge, not so for those without knowledge.

original: natu 'yajñena vividiṣanti' iti atra aviśeṣeṇa ātmajñānāṅgatvena śrutasya agnihotrādeḥ anaṅgatvaṃ śakyam abhyupagantum /
analyzed: na tu yajñena vividiṣanti iti atra aviśeṣeṇa ātma jñāna aṅga tvena śrutasya agnihotra ādeḥ anaṅga tvam śakyam abhyupagantum
translated: But it is not possible to accept that the Agnihotra and so on, which are heard as the means of knowledge of the Self without distinction in the statement, 'By sacrifice they seek to know,' are not the means.

original: tathā hi śrutiḥ 'yadeva vidyayā karoti śraddhayopaniṣadā tadeva vīryavattaraṃ bhavati' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ yat eva vidyayā karoti śraddhayā upaniṣadā tat eva vīryavattaram bhavati chā
translated: For thus the Śruti says, 'Whatever one does with knowledge, faith, and the Upaniṣad, that becomes most powerful.' (Chā.

original: iti vidyāsaṃyuktasya karmaṇaḥ agnihotrādeḥ vīryavattaratva abhidhānena svakāryaṃ
analyzed: iti vidyā saṃyuktasya karmaṇaḥ agnihotra ādeḥ vīryavattara tva abhidhānena svakāryam
translated: Thus, by declaring the superiority of the ritual action such as Agnihotra etc. when combined with knowledge, it shows that it has some superiority in accomplishing its own purpose.

original: prati kañcit atiśayaṃ bruvāṇā vidyāvihīnasya tasya eva tat prayojanaṃ prati vīryavattvaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: prati kañcid atiśayam bruvāṇāḥ vidyā vihīnasya tasya eva tat prayojanam prati vīryavat tvam darśayati
translated: It shows that the same action devoid of knowledge is also powerful in accomplishing that purpose.

original: karmaṇa ca vīryavattvaṃ tat yat svaprayojanasādhanaprasahatvam /
analyzed: karmaṇa ca vīryavat tvam tat yat sva prayojana sādhana prasaha tvam
translated: And the power of an action consists in its ability to accomplish its own purpose.

original: tasmāt vidyāsaṃyuktaṃ nityam agnihotrādi vidyāvihīnaṃ ca ubhayam api mumukṣuṇā mokṣaprayojana
analyzed: tasmāt vidyā saṃyuktam nityam agnihotra ādi vidyā vihīnam ca ubhayam api mumukṣuṇā mokṣa prayojana
translated: Therefore, both the eternal Agnihotra etc. combined with knowledge and those performed without knowledge, by one who desires liberation, for the purpose of attaining liberation,

original: uddeśena iha janmani janmāntare ca prāk jñāna utpatteḥ kṛtaṃ yat tat yathāsāmarthyaṃ
analyzed: uddeśena iha janmani janmāntare ca prāk jñāna utpatteḥ kṛtam yat tat yathāsāmarthyam
translated: the rites performed in this life or in previous lives before the arising of knowledge, to the extent of one's ability,

original: brahma adhigamapratibandhakāraṇa upāttaduritakṣayahetutvadvāreṇa brahma adhigamakāraṇatvaṃ🔽pratipadyamānaṃ śravaṇa manana śraddhā tātparyādi antaraṅgakāraṇāpekṣaṃ brahmavidyayā
analyzed: pratipadyamānam śravaṇa manana śraddhā tātparya ādi antaraṅga kāraṇa apekṣam brahma vidyayā
translated: become the cause of attaining Brahman by way of destroying the demerit acquired which is an impediment to the realization of Brahman.

original: saha ekakāryaṃ bhavati iti sthitam // //
analyzed: saha eka kāryam bhavati iti sthitam  /
translated: It is established that they, along with the internal causes such as listening, reflection, faith, and devotion, have the same effect as the knowledge of Brahman.

original: itarakṣapaṇa adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: itarakṣapaṇa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the refutation of other paths. Sutra.

original: bhogena tv itare kṣapayitvātha saṃpadyate / / / /
analyzed: bhogena tu itare kṣapayitvā atha saṃpadyate  /
translated: But the other two, having exhausted them by experience, then attains identity.

original: anārabdhakāryayoḥ puṇyapāpayoḥ vidyāsāmarthyāt kṣaya uktaḥ itare tu ārabdhakārye
analyzed: anārabdha kāryayoḥ puṇya pāpayoḥ vidyā sāmarthyāt kṣayaḥ uktaḥ itare tu ārabdha kārye
translated: The exhaustion of merit and demerit whose effects have not begun is stated to be due to the power of knowledge. But the other two, whose effects have begun,

original: puṇyapāpe upabhogena kṣapayitvā brahma saṃpadyate 'tasya tāvadeva ciraṃ yāvanna vimokṣye🔽'tha saṃpatsye' chāndo / / /
analyzed: puṇya pāpe upabhogena kṣapayitvā brahma saṃpadyate tasya tāvat eva ciram yāvat na vimokṣye  tha saṃpatsye chāndaḥ
translated: are exhausted by experience and then one attains Brahman. As it is said: For him it is a long time until he is released from this body,🔽until he attains identity with Brahman. (Ch. U. 8.15.1)

original: iti 'brahmaiva sanbrahmāpyeti' iti ca evamādiśrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: iti brahma eva san brahma apyeti iti ca evamādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: And by such Vedic texts as Having become Brahman, he goes to Brahman. (Br. U. 4.4.22)

original: nanu sati api samyak darśane yathā prāk dehapātāt bhedadarśanaṃ dvicandradarśananyāyena anuvṛttamevaṃ paścāt api anuvarteta / na /
analyzed: nanu sati api samyak darśane yathā prāk dehapātāt bheda darśanam dvi candra darśana nyāyena anuvṛttam evam paścāt api anuvarteta na
translated: But even if there is right knowledge, just as the perception of difference continues before the fall of the body according to the analogy of the perception of two moons, so it would continue afterwards also. No.

original: nimitta abhāvāt /
analyzed: nimitta abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause.

original: upabhogaśeṣakṣapaṇaṃ hi tatra anuvṛttinimittaṃ na ca tādṛśamātra kiñcit asti /
analyzed: upabhoga śeṣa kṣapaṇam hi tatra anuvṛtti nimittam na ca tādṛśa mātra kiñcid asti
translated: For the cause of its continuation there is the exhaustion of the remainder of experience. And there is nothing like that at all.

original: nanu aparaḥ karmāśayoḥ abhinavam upabhogm ārapsyate / na /
analyzed: nanu aparaḥ karma āśayoḥ abhinavam upabhogm ārapsyate na
translated: But another heap of karma will begin a new experience. No.

original: tasya dagdhabījatvāt /
analyzed: tasya dagdha bīja tvāt
translated: Because that is like a burnt seed.

original: mithyājñāna avaṣṭambhaṃ hi karmāntaraṃ dehapāta upabhogāntaram ārabhate tat ca mithyājñāna
analyzed: mithyājñāna avaṣṭambham hi karmāntaram dehapāta upabhoga antaram ārabhate tat ca mithyājñāna
translated: For another karma, supported by false knowledge, begins another experience after the fall of the body. And that false knowledge

original: avaṣṭambhaṃ hi karmāntaraṃ dehapāta upabhogāntaram ārabhate tatca mithyājñānaṃ samyak
analyzed: avaṣṭambham hi karma antaram dehapāte upabhoga antaram ārabhate tat ca mithyājñānam samyak
translated: For a different action, which is a support, begins a different experience after the fall of the body, and that is false knowledge, which is rightly abandoned by the knowledge of the truth.

original: jñānena dagdham ityataḥ sādhu etat ārabdhakāryakṣaye viduṣaḥ kaivalyam avaśyaṃ bhavati iti // //
analyzed: jñānena dagdham iti atas sādhu etat ārabdha kārya kṣaye viduṣaḥ kaivalyam avaśyam bhavati iti  /
translated: For a different action, which is the support, begins a different experience at the time of the fall of the body. And that false knowledge is burned by right knowledge. Therefore this is good: when the results of actions begun are exhausted, the wise one certainly attains liberation.

original: iti śrīgovindabhagavatpūjyapādaśiṣyaśrīmacchaṅkarabhagavatpādakṛtau śārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye caturthādhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrī govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣya śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye caturtha adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the first chapter of the fourth section in the commentary of Shri Shankar Bhagavatpada, the disciple of the venerable Shri Govinda Bhagavatpada, on the Vedanta Sutras.

original: caturthādhyāye dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ /
analyzed: caturtha adhyāye dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ
translated: The second chapter of the fourth section.

original: atra pāde utkrāntigatinirūpaṇam
analyzed: atra pāde utkrānti gati nirūpaṇam
translated: In this chapter, the determination of the path of departure.

original: vāgādhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: vāga adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on speech. Sutra.

original: vāṅmanasi darśanāc chabdāc ca / / / /
analyzed: vāc manasi darśanāt śabdāt ca
translated: Because of the seeing in the mind and because of the word.

original: atha aparāsu vidyāsu phalaprāptaye devayānaṃ panthānam avatārayiṣyan prathamaṃ tāvat yathāśāstram utkrāntikramam anvācaṣṭe /
analyzed: atha aparāsu vidyāsu phala prāptaye deva yānam panthānam avatārayiṣyan prathamam tāvat yathāśāstram utkrānti kramam anvācaṣṭe
translated: Now, intending to lead to the path of the gods for the attainment of the fruits in the other vidyas, he first describes the sequence of departure according to the scriptures.

original: samānā hi vidvat aviduṣoḥ utkrāntiḥ iti vakṣyati /
analyzed: samānā hi vidvat aviduṣoḥ utkrāntiḥ iti vakṣyati
translated: For he will say that the departure of the wise and the ignorant is the same.

original: asti prāyaṇaviṣayā śrutiḥ 'asya somya puruṣasya prayato vāk manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇa tejasi tejaḥ parasyāṃ devatāyām' chā / / / 🔽iti /🔽kim iha vāca eva vṛttimattyā manasi saṃpattiḥ ucyata uta vāgvṛtteḥiti viśayaḥ /
analyzed: asti prāyaṇa viṣayā śrutiḥ asya somya puruṣasya prayataḥ vāc manasi saṃpadyate manaḥ prāṇe prāṇa tejasi tejaḥ parasyām devatāyām chā  / iti  kim iha vācaḥ eva vṛttimattyā manasi saṃpattiḥ ucyate uta vāc vṛtteḥ iti viśayaḥ
translated: There is a text referring to the time of death: 'This person's speech, my dear, is dissolved in the mind, the mind in the life-breath, the life-breath in the heat, the heat in the highest deity' (Chānd. 8.6.6).🔽Here the doubt is whether the speech itself, along with its function, is dissolved in the mind, or only the function of speech.

original: tatra vāk eva tāvat manasi saṃpadyata iti prāptam /
analyzed: tatra vāc eva tāvat manasi saṃpadyate iti prāptam
translated: Here, it is first established that the speech itself is dissolved in the mind.

original: tathā hi śrutiḥ anugṛhītā bhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ anugṛhītā bhavati
translated: For in this way the text is favored.

original: itarathā lakṣaṇā syāt /
analyzed: itarathā lakṣaṇā syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a figurative interpretation.

original: śrutilakṣaṇa aviśaye ca śrutiḥ nyāyyā na lakṣaṇā /
analyzed: śruti lakṣaṇa aviśaye ca śrutiḥ nyāyyā na lakṣaṇā
translated: And in a case where there is a choice between a literal interpretation and a figurative one, the literal interpretation is proper, not the figurative one.

original: tasmāt vāca eva ayaṃ manasi pralaya iti /
analyzed: tasmāt vācaḥ eva ayam manasi pralayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, this dissolution of speech is in the mind.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ vāk vṛttiḥ iti vyākhyāte yāvatā vāk menasi iti eva ācāryaḥ paṭhati /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ vāc vṛttiḥ iti vyākhyāte yāvatā vāc menasi iti eva ācāryaḥ paṭhati
translated: When this is the case, we say that the function of speech is dissolved, because the teacher reads 'speech in the mind' itself.

original: satyam etat /
analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

original: paṭhiṣyati tu purastāt 'avibhāgo vacanāt' bra / sū / / / iti /
analyzed: paṭhiṣyati tu purastāt avibhāgaḥ vacanāt bra sū iti
translated: But he will read earlier: 'The undifferentiated is stated' (Br. Sū. 2.3.1).

original: tasmāt atra vṛtti upaśamamātraṃ vivakṣitam iti gamyate /
analyzed: tasmāt atra vṛtti upaśama mātram vivakṣitam iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, here it is understood that only the cessation of the function is intended.

original: tattvapralayavivakṣāyāṃ tu sarvatra eva avibhāgasāmyāt kiṃ paratra eva viśiṣyāt avibhāga iti /
analyzed: tattva pralaya vivakṣāyām tu sarvatra eva avibhāga sāmyāt kim paratra eva viśiṣyāt avibhāgaḥ iti
translated: But if the dissolution of the elements is meant, then everywhere there is the same non-distinction. So what is the point of singling out non-distinction in the case of the supreme self alone?

original: tasmāt atra vṛtti upasaṃhāravivakṣā /
analyzed: tasmāt atra vṛtti upasaṃhāra vivakṣā
translated: Therefore, in this case, the dissolution of the modifications is meant.

original: vāk vṛttiḥ pūrvam upasaṃhriyate manovṛttau avasthitāyām iti arthaḥ /
analyzed: vāc vṛttiḥ pūrvam upasaṃhriyate manovṛttau avasthitāyām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the modification of speech is dissolved first when the modification of the mind remains.

original: kasmāt /
analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: darśanāt /
analyzed: darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen.

original: dṛśyate hi vāk vṛtteḥ pūrva upasaṃhāro manovṛttau vidyamānāyām /
analyzed: dṛśyate hi vāc vṛtteḥ pūrvaḥ upasaṃhāraḥ manaḥ vṛttau vidyamānāyām
translated: It is seen that the dissolution of the modification of speech occurs first when the modification of the mind exists.

original: nanu śrutisāmarthyāt vāca eva ayaṃ manasi apyayo yukta iti uktam /
analyzed: nanu śruti sāmarthyāt vācaḥ eva ayam manasi apyayaḥ yuktaḥ iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that due to the power of the Vedic text, it is proper that the dissolution of speech alone occurs in the mind.

original: na iti āha /
analyzed: na iti āha
translated: The author says no.

original: atatprakṛtitvāt /
analyzed: a tad prakṛti tvāt
translated: Because it is not its cause.

original: yasya hi yata utpattiḥ tasya tatra pralayo nyāyyo mṛdīva śarāvasya /
analyzed: yasya hi yatas utpattiḥ tasya tatra pralayaḥ nyāyyaḥ mṛdi iva śarāvasya
translated: The dissolution of that which is produced from something is proper in that, like a pot from clay.

original: na ca manaso vāk utpadyata iti kiñcana pramāṇam asti /
analyzed: na ca manasaḥ vāc utpadyate iti kiñcana pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no evidence at all that speech is produced from the mind.

original: vṛttyutti udbhava abhibhavau tu aprakṛtisamāśrayau api dṛśyete /
analyzed: vṛtti utti udbhava abhibhavau tu aprakṛti samāśrayau api dṛśyete
translated: But the origination and submergence of modifications are seen even without a common cause.

original: pārthivebhyo hi indhanebhyaḥ taijasasya agneḥ vṛttiḥ udbhavati apsu ca upaśāmyati /
analyzed: pārthivebhyaḥ hi indhanebhyaḥ taijasasya agneḥ vṛttiḥ udbhavati apsu ca upaśāmyati
translated: For the modification of fire, which is luminous, originates from fuel which is earthy, and is extinguished in water.

original: kathaṃ tarhi asmin pakṣe śabdo vāk manasi saṃpadyata iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi asmin pakṣe śabdaḥ vāc manasi saṃpadyate iti
translated: How then, in this view, does speech become united with mind in the form of sound?

original: ata āha śabdāt ca iti /
analyzed: atas āha śabdāt ca iti
translated: To this he says: And from sound.

original: śabdaḥ api asmin pakṣe avakalpate vṛttivṛttimatoḥ abheda upacārāt iti arthaḥ // //
analyzed: śabdaḥ api asmin pakṣe avakalpate vṛtti vṛttimatoḥ abheda upacārāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even in this view, sound is possible, because there is no difference between the function and the possessor of the function, due to figurative usage.

original: FN / prayato mriyamāṇasya /
analyzed: prayataḥ mriyamāṇasya
translated: One who is pure dies.

original: ata eva ca sarvāṇyanu / / / /
analyzed: atas eva ca sarvāṇi anu
translated: And for this very reason, all [sense organs].

original: 'tasmādupaśāntatejāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt upaśānta tejāḥ
translated: Therefore, his radiant energy becomes pacified.

original: punarbhavamindriyairmanasi saṃpadyamānaiḥ' praśna / /
analyzed: punarbhavam indriyaiḥ manasi saṃpadyamānaiḥ praśna
translated: Again, through the sense organs becoming united with the mind, he is reborn. - Question

original: iti atra aviśeṣeṇa sarveṣām eva indriyāṇāṃ manasi saṃpattiḥ śrūyate /
analyzed: iti atra aviśeṣeṇa sarveṣām eva indriyāṇām manasi saṃpattiḥ śrūyate
translated: Here, without distinction, the union of all the sense organs with the mind is heard.

original: tatra api ata eva vāca iva cakṣurādīnām api savṛttike manasi avasthite vṛttilopadarśanāt
analyzed: tatra api atas eva vācaḥ iva cakṣuḥ ādīnām api sa vṛttike manasi avasthite vṛtti lopa darśanāt
translated: Even there, for this very reason, like speech, the eyes and so on also remain in the mind with its function, because the cessation of function is shown.

original: tattvapralaya asaṃbhavāt śabda upapatteḥ ca vṛttidvāreṇa eva sarvāṇi indriyāṇi manaḥ anuvartante /
analyzed: tattva pralaya asaṃbhavāt śabda upapatteḥ ca vṛttidvāreṇa eva sarvāṇi indriyāṇi manaḥ anuvartante
translated: And because of the possibility of sound, all the sense organs follow the mind only through the door of function, due to the impossibility of their complete dissolution.

original: sarveṣāṃ karaṇānāṃ manasi upasaṃhāra aviśeṣe sati vācaḥ pṛthak grahaṇaṃ vāk manasi saṃpadyata iti udāharaṇa anurodhena // //
analyzed: sarveṣām karaṇānām manasi upasaṃhāra aviśeṣe sati vācaḥ pṛthak grahaṇam vāc manasi saṃpadyata iti udāharaṇa anurodhena  /
translated: Even when there is no distinction in the withdrawal of all the organs into the mind, the separate mention of speech, as in speech becomes united with the mind, is in accordance with the example.

original: manodhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: manaḥ adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the mind. Sutra.

original: tanmanaḥ prāṇa uttarāt / / / /
analyzed: tat manaḥ prāṇaḥ uttarāt
translated: That mind merges into the lifebreath, from the next verse.

original: samadhigatametat 'vāṅmanasi saṃpadyate' chā / / /
analyzed: samadhigatam etat vāc manasi saṃpadyate chā
translated: It has been understood here that 'speech merges into mind' (Ch. Up. 6.8.3),

original: iti atra vṛttisaṃpattivivakṣa iti /
analyzed: iti atra vṛtti saṃpatti vivakṣaḥ iti
translated: this is stated with reference to the merging of the function.

original: atha yat uttaravākyam 'manaḥ prāṇe' chā / / /
analyzed: atha yat uttaravākyam manaḥ prāṇe chā
translated: Now, as for the next statement 'mind merges into lifebreath' (Ch. Up. 6.8.3),

original: iti kim atra api vṛttisaṃpattiḥ eva vivakṣyata uta vṛttimat saṃpattiḥ iti vicikitsāyāṃ vṛttimat saṃpattiḥ eva atra iti prāptam /
analyzed: iti kim atra api vṛtti saṃpattiḥ eva vivakṣyate uta vṛttimat saṃpattiḥ iti vicikitsāyām vṛttimat saṃpattiḥ eva atra iti prāptam
translated: is the merging of the function alone intended here, or the merging of that which has the function? In the doubt, it is concluded that the merging of that which has the function alone is intended here.

original: śruti anugrahāt tat prakṛtikatva upapatteḥ ca /🔽tathā hi 'annamayaṃ hi somya mana āpomayaḥprāṇaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: śruti anugrahāt tat prakṛtikatva upapatteḥ ca  tathā hi anna mayam hi somya manaḥ āpaḥ mayaḥ prāṇaḥ chā
translated: Because it is supported by the śruti and because it is proper that it should have that as its material cause.🔽For thus, 'Verily, O Śvetaketu, the mind is made of food, the lifebreath is made of water' (Ch. Up. 6.5.4).

original: iti annayoni mana ātmananti ap yoniṃ ca prāṇam /
analyzed: iti annayoni manaḥ ātmananti ap yonim ca prāṇam
translated: Thus the mind is stated to have food as its source, and the lifebreath to have water as its source.

original: 'āpaścānnamasṛjanta' iti śrutiḥ /
analyzed: āpaḥ ca annam asṛjanta iti śrutiḥ
translated: The śruti says, 'Water produced food' (Ch. Up. 6.2.1).

original: ata ca yat manaḥ prāṇe prakṛtivikāra abhedāt iti /
analyzed: ata ca yat manaḥ prāṇe prakṛtivikāra abhedāt iti
translated: Therefore, the mind merges into the lifebreath because of the non-difference of the material cause and the effect.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ tat api agṛhīta bāhya indriyavṛtti mano vṛttidvāreṇa eva prāṇe pralīyate iti uttarāt vākyāt avagantavyam /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ tat api agṛhīta bāhya indriya vṛtti manaḥ vṛtti dvāreṇa eva prāṇe pralīyate iti uttarāt vākyāt avagantavyam
translated: When this is the case, we say that even that mind, whose function of apprehending external objects has not ceased, dissolves into the lifebreath through the door of its own function, this should be understood from the next statement.

original: tathā hi suṣupso mumūrṣoḥ ca prāṇavṛttau parispanda ātmikāyām avasthitāyāṃ manovṛttīnām upaśamo dṛśyate /
analyzed: tathā hi suṣupsaḥ mumūrṣoḥ ca prāṇa vṛttau parispanda ātmikāyām avasthitāyām manaḥ vṛttīnām upaśamaḥ dṛśyate
