analyzed: yatra avidyā kṛta nāma rūpa ādi viśeṣa pratiṣedhāt asthūla ādi śabdaiḥ brahma upadiśyate tat param
translated: That where Brahman is taught by words like 'not gross' etc. by negating the particulars created by ignorance, such as name and form, that is the supreme.

original: tat eva yatra nāmarūpādiviśeṣeṇa kenacit viśiṣṭam upāsanāya upadiśyate 'manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīro bhārūpaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: tat eva yatra nāma rūpa ādi viśeṣeṇa kenacid viśiṣṭam upāsanāya upadiśyate manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ chā
translated: That same Brahman, where it is taught for the purpose of meditation as qualified by some particular name and form, such as 'consisting of mind, having life as its body, having light as its form,'

original: ityādiśabdaistadaparam /
analyzed: ityādi śabdaiḥ tat aparam
translated: etc., by words like that, that is the lower.

original: nanu evam advitīyaśrutiḥ uparudhyeta / na /
analyzed: nanu evam advitīyaśrutiḥ uparudhyeta na
translated: But in that case, the teaching of non-duality would be contradicted? No,

original: avidyākṛta nāma rūpa upādhikatayā parihṛtatvāt /🔽tasya ca aparabrahma upāsanasya tat saṃnidhau śrūyamāṇam 'sa yadi pitṛlokakāmo bhavati' chā / / /
analyzed: avidyā kṛta nāma rūpa upādhikatayā parihṛta tvāt  tasya ca aparabrahma upāsanasya tat saṃnidhau śrūyamāṇam sa yadi pitṛ loka kāmaḥ bhavati chā
translated: because that has been refuted by being qualified by name and form created by ignorance.🔽And the fruit of that meditation on the lower Brahman, which is heard in its proximity, such as 'If he desires the world of the ancestors,'

original: ityādi jagat aiśvaryalakṣaṇaṃ saṃsāragocaram eva phalaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ityādi jagat aiśvarya lakṣaṇam saṃsāra gocaram eva phalam bhavati
translated: etc., is the worldly experience characterized by lordship over the world.

original: anivartitatvāt avidyāyāḥ /
analyzed: a nivartita tvāt avidyāyāḥ
translated: Because ignorance has not been removed.

original: tasya ca deśaviśeṣa avabaddhatvāt tatprāptyarthaṃ gamanam aviruddham /
analyzed: tasya ca deśa viśeṣa avabaddha tvāt tad prāpti artham gamanam aviruddham
translated: And since that (Brahman) is connected with a particular place, it is not contradictory to go in order to attain it.

original: sarvagatatve api ca ātmana ākāśasya iva ghaṭādigamane budhyādi upādhigamane gamanaprasiddhiḥ iti avādiṣma 'tadguṇasāratvāt' bra /sū / / /
analyzed: sarvagata tve api ca ātmanaḥ ākāśasya iva ghaṭa ādi gamane budhi ādi upādhi gamane gamana prasiddhiḥ iti avādiṣma tad guṇa sāra tvāt brasū
translated: And even if the Self is all-pervading, we have said that the idea of going is established in the case of the Self's going to the ear, etc., which are limiting adjuncts, just as in the case of space going to the pot, etc.

original: ityatra /🔽tasmāt 'kāryaṃ bādariḥ bra / sū / / /
analyzed: iti atra  tasmāt kāryam bādariḥ
translated: This is stated in the Brahmasutra (3.2.15).

original: ityeṣa eva sthitaḥ pakṣaḥ /🔽'paraṃ jaiminiḥ' bra /sū / / /
analyzed: iti eṣaḥ eva sthitaḥ pakṣaḥ  param jaiminiḥ brasū
translated: Therefore, this very view of Badarayana (that the Self goes to the effect) remains.

original: iti tu pakṣāntarapratibhānamātrapradarśanaṃ prajñāvikāsanāya iti draṣṭavyam // //
analyzed: iti tu pakṣa antara pratibhāna mātra pradarśanam prajñā vikāsanāya iti draṣṭavyam  /
translated: But the view of Jaimini (that the Self does not go) is stated merely to show another possibility, in order to develop wisdom. This is how it should be seen.

original: apratīka ālambana adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: apratīka ālambana adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the object of meditation being without form. Sutra.

original: apratīkālambanān nayatīti bādarāyaṇa ubhayathā ca doṣāt tatkratuś ca / / / /
analyzed: a pratīka ālambanāt nayati iti bādarāyaṇaḥ ubhayathā ca doṣāt tad kratuḥ ca
translated: Badarayana says that it leads to the object of meditation without form, and also because there is fault in both ways, and because of the resolve for that.

original: sthitam etat kāryaviṣayā gatiḥ na paraviṣayā iti /
analyzed: sthitam etat kārya viṣayā gatiḥ na para viṣayā iti
translated: This has been established: the going is to the effect, not to the supreme.

original: idam idānīṃ saṃdihyate kiṃ sarvān vikāra ālambanān aviśeṣeṇa eva amānavaḥ puruṣaḥ prāpayati brahmalokam uta kāṃścit eva iti /
analyzed: idam idānīm saṃdihyate kim sarvān vikāra ālambanān aviśeṣeṇa eva amānavaḥ puruṣaḥ prāpayati brahmalokam uta kāṃścid eva iti
translated: Now this is doubted: Does the non-human being lead all those who have objects of change as their support to the world of Brahman, without distinction, or only some?

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptaṃ sarveṣām eva eṣāṃ viduṣām anyatra parasmāt brahṇaṇo gatiḥ syāt /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam sarveṣām eva eṣām viduṣām anyatra parasmāt brahṇaṇaḥ gatiḥ syāt
translated: What is the prima facie view? The goal of all these wise men is the same, namely, Brahman.

original: tathā hi 'aniyamaḥ sarvāsām' bra / sū / / /
analyzed: tathā hi aniyamaḥ sarvāsām bra sū
translated: For thus it is said in the Brahmasutra, There is no restriction as to all of them (Br. Sū. 4.1.16).

original: iti atrāviśeṣeṇa eva eṣāṃ vidyāntareṣu avatārita iti /
analyzed: iti atra aviśeṣeṇa eva eṣām vidyā antareṣu avatāritaḥ iti
translated: Here it is stated without distinction that they are included among the other meditations.

original: evaṃ prāpte pratyāha apratīka ālambanān iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte pratyāha apratīka ālambanān iti
translated: When this is the prima facie view, the author replies: Because they have Brahman as their object, not the symbols.

original: pratīka ālambanān varjayitvā sarvān anyān vikāra ālambanān nayati brahmalokam iti bādarāyaṇa ācāryo manyate /
analyzed: pratīka ālambanān varjayitvā sarvān anyān vikāra ālambanān nayati brahma lokam iti bādarāyaṇaḥ ācāryaḥ manyate
translated: The teacher Bādarāyaṇa thinks that all other meditations, except those that have symbols as their objects, lead to the world of Brahman.

original: na hi evam ubhayathā
analyzed: na hi evam ubhayathā
translated: For it is not so in both ways.

original: abhāva abhyupagame kaścit doṣaḥ asti /
analyzed: abhāva abhyupagame kaścid doṣaḥ asti
translated: There is no fault in accepting the absence of restriction.

original: aniyama nyāyasya pratīkavyatirikteṣu api upāsaneṣu upapatteḥ /
analyzed: aniyama nyāyasya pratīkavyatirikteṣu api upāsaneṣu upapatteḥ
translated: Because the principle of non-restriction is applicable to meditations other than those on symbols.

original: tatkratuḥ ca asya ubhayathābhāvasya samarthako hetuḥ draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: tad kratuḥ ca asya ubhayathābhāvasya samarthakaḥ hetuḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The fact that they have Brahman as their object is to be seen as the reason that supports the existence of both.

original: yo hi brahmakratuḥ sa brāhmam aiśvaryam āsīdediti śliṣyate 'taṃ yathā yatopāsate tadeva bhavati' iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ hi brahma kratuḥ sa brāhmam aiśvaryam āsīdet iti śliṣyate tam yathā yatā upāsate tat eva bhavati iti śruteḥ
translated: For it is connected that he who has the resolve for Brahman attains Brahman's lordship, according to the Vedic text One becomes that upon which one has the resolve.

original: na tu pratīkeṣu brahma akratutvam asti pratīkapradhānatvāt upāsanasya /
analyzed: na tu pratīkeṣu brahma akratu tvam asti pratīka pradhāna tvāt upāsanasya
translated: But the symbols do not have Brahman as their object, because the meditation is primarily focused on the symbols.

original: nanu abrahmakratuḥ api brahmagacchati iti śrūyate yathā pañcāgni vidyāyām 'sa enānbrahma gamayati' chā / / /
analyzed: nanu abrahma kratuḥ api brahmagacchati iti śrūyate yathā pañcāgni vidyāyām saḥ enān brahma gamayati chā
translated: But it is heard that one who does not have the thought of Brahman also goes to Brahman, as in the Pañcāgni Vidyā: 'He leads them to Brahman' (Chā. 7.26.2).

original: iti bhavatu yatra evam āhatyavāda upalabhyate tat abhāve tu autsargikeṇa tat kratunyāyena brahmakratūnām eva tatprāptiḥ na itareṣām iti gamyate
analyzed: iti bhavatu yatra evam āhatyavādaḥ upalabhyate tad abhāve tu autsargikeṇa tad kratu nyāyena brahma kratūnām eva tad prāptiḥ na itareṣām iti gamyate
translated: Let it be so where such a concluding statement is found. But in its absence, due to the natural rule of that thought, only those with the thought of Brahman attain it, not others.

original: viśeṣaṃ ca darśayati / / / /
analyzed: viśeṣam ca darśayati
translated: And it shows a distinction.

original: nāmādiṣu pratīka upāsaneṣu pūrvasmāt pūrvasmāt phalaviśeṣam uttarasmin uttarasmin upāsane darśayati 'yāvannāmno gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro 🔽bhavati' chā / / /
analyzed: nāma ādiṣu pratīke upāsaneṣu pūrvasmāt pūrvasmāt phala viśeṣam uttarasmin uttarasmin upāsane darśayati yāvat nāmnaḥ gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ  bhavati chā
translated: In the meditations on symbols such as name, it shows a difference in the results in each subsequent meditation from each preceding one: 'As far as name goes, there one has freedom to act as one wishes' (Chā. 7.1.5).

original: 'vāgvāva nāmno bhūyasī' chā / / /
analyzed: vāc vāva nāmnaḥ bhūyasī chā
translated: 'Speech indeed is greater than name' (Chā. 7.1.6).

original: 'yāvadvāco gataṃ tatrāsya yathākāmacāro bhavati'chā / / /
analyzed: yāvat vācaḥ gatam tatra asya yathākāma cāraḥ bhavati ichā
translated: 'As far as speech goes, there one has freedom to act as one wishes' (Chā. 7.1.6).

original: 'mano vāva vāco bhūyaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: manaḥ vāva vācaḥ bhūyaḥ chā
translated: 'Mind indeed is greater than speech' (Chā. 7.1.7).

original: ityādinā /
analyzed: ityādinā
translated: And so on.

original: sa ca ayaṃ phalaviśeṣaḥ pratīka tantratvāt upāsanānām upapadyate /
analyzed: sa ca ayam phala viśeṣaḥ pratīka tantra tvāt upāsanānām upapadyate
translated: And this difference in results is possible in the meditations on symbols, because they depend on symbols.

original: brahma tantratve tu brahmaṇaḥ aviśiṣṭatvāt kathaṃ phalaviśeṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: brahma tantra tve tu brahmaṇaḥ aviśiṣṭa tvāt katham phala viśeṣaḥ syāt
translated: But if they depended on Brahman, since Brahman is undifferentiated, how could there be a difference in results?

original: tasmāt na pratīka ālambanānām itaraiḥ tulyaphalatvam iti // //
analyzed: tasmāt na pratīka ālambanānām itaraiḥ tulya phala tvam iti
translated: Therefore, those who have symbols as their object do not have the same result as others.

original: iti śrīgovindabhagavatpūjyapādaśiṣyaśrīśaṅkarabhagavatpādakṛtau śrīmacchārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye caturthādhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ pādaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrī govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣya śrī śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau śrīmat śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye caturtha adhyāyasya tṛtīyaḥ pādaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the third chapter of the fourth section in the commentary of the revered teacher Shankara, the disciple of the revered teacher Govinda, on the sacred Shabara-Bhashya.

original: caturtho 'dhyāye caturthaḥ pādaḥ /🔽atra pāde brahmaprāptibrahmalokasthitinirūpaṇam
analyzed: caturthaḥ dhyāye caturthaḥ pādaḥ  atra pāde brahma prāpti brahma loka sthiti nirūpaṇam
translated: Fourth chapter, fourth section.

original: saṃpadyāvirbhāva adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: saṃpadya āvirbhāva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: In this section, the determination of the attainment of Brahman and the abiding in the world of Brahman.🔽The section on the manifestation of prosperity. Sutra.

original: saṃpadyāvirbhāvaḥ svena śabdāt / / / /
analyzed: saṃpadya āvirbhāvaḥ svena śabdāt
translated: The manifestation of prosperity is by one's own word.

original: evam eva eṣa saṃprasādaḥ asmāt śarīrāt samutthāya paraṃ jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata iti śrūyate /
analyzed: evam eva eṣa saṃprasādaḥ asmāt śarīrāt samutthāya param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate iti śrūyate
translated: Thus it is heard that this well-being, rising up from this body, attains the supreme light and manifests in its own form.

original: tatra saṃśayaḥ kiṃ devalokādi upabhogasthāneṣu iva āgantukena kenacit viśeṣeṇa abhiniṣpadyata āhot ātmamātreṇa iti /
analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim deva loka ādi upabhoga sthāneṣu iva āgantukena kenacid viśeṣeṇa abhiniṣpadyate āho ut ātma mātreṇa iti
translated: There is doubt - does it manifest by some adventitious special quality, as in the places of enjoyment like the world of gods, or by the self alone?

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptam /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: sthānāntareṣu iva āgantukena kenacit rūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ syāt /
analyzed: sthāna antareṣu iva āgantukena kenacid rūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ syāt
translated: The manifestation would be by some adventitious form, as in other places.

original: mokṣasya api phalatvaprasiddheḥ /
analyzed: mokṣasya api phala tva prasiddheḥ
translated: Because liberation is known to be a result.

original: abhiniṣpadyata iti ca utpattiparyāyatvāt /
analyzed: abhiniṣpadyate iti ca utpatti paryāya tvāt
translated: And 'it is accomplished' is a synonym for 'arising'.

original: svarūpamātreṇa cet abhiniṣpattiḥ pūrvāsu api avasthāsu svarūpa anāpāyāt vibhāvyeta /
analyzed: svarūpamātreṇa ced abhiniṣpattiḥ pūrvāsu api avasthāsu svarūpa anāpāyāt vibhāvyeta
translated: If accomplishment were by one's own nature alone, it would be perceived in the previous stages also, because one's own nature is not absent.

original: tasmāt viśeṣeṇa kenacit abhiniṣpadyata iti /
analyzed: tasmāt viśeṣeṇa kenacid abhiniṣpadyata iti
translated: Therefore, it is accomplished by some distinction.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ kevalena eva ātmana āvirbhavati na dharmāntareṇa iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ kevalena eva ātmanaḥ āvirbhavati na dharma antareṇa iti
translated: When this is the case, we say it manifests only by one's own self, not by another dharma.

original: kutaḥ svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata iti svaśabdāt /
analyzed: kutas svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate iti sva śabdāt
translated: Why? Because of the word 'sva' (one's own).

original: anyathā hi svaśabdena iti viśeṣaṇam anavakḷptaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā hi sva śabdena iti viśeṣaṇam anavakḷptam syāt
translated: For otherwise, the qualification 'by one's own' would be meaningless.

original: nanu ātmīya abhiprāyaḥ svaśabdo bhaviṣyati / na /
analyzed: nanu ātmīya abhiprāyaḥ svaśabdaḥ bhaviṣyati na
translated: But won't the word 'sva' (one's own) have the meaning of 'belonging to the self'? No.

original: tasya avacanīyatvāt /🔽yena eva hi kenacit rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate tasya eva ātmīyatva upapatteḥ svena iti viśeṣaṇamna arthakaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasya avacanīya tvāt  yena eva hi kenacid rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate tasya eva ātmīya tva upapatteḥ svena iti viśeṣaṇamna arthakam syāt
translated: Because that cannot be expressed.🔽For if it were accomplished by some other form, it would be reasonable for that itself to be one's own, so the qualification 'by one's own' would be meaningless.

original: ātmavacanatāyāṃ tu arthavat kevalena eva ātmarūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate na āgantukena apararūpeṇāpi iti // //
analyzed: ātma vacanatāyām tu arthavat kevalena eva ātma rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate na āgantukena apara rūpeṇa api iti
translated: But when it has the meaning of 'self', it is meaningful. It is accomplished only by one's own self-nature, not even by any other adventitious form.

original: kaḥ punaḥ viśeṣaḥ pūrvāsu avasthāsu iha ca svarūpa anapāyasāmye sati ityata āha
analyzed: kaḥ punar viśeṣaḥ pūrvāsu avasthāsu iha ca svarūpa anapāya sāmye sati iti atas āha
translated: What, then, is the difference between the previous states and this one, if there is the same absence of loss of nature? To this he says:

original: muktaḥ pratijñānāt / / / /
analyzed: muktaḥ pratijñānāt
translated: He is liberated, because of the promise.

original: yaḥ atra abhiniṣpadyata iti uktaḥ sa sarvabandha vinirmuktaḥ śuddhena eva ātmanā avatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: yaḥ atra abhiniṣpadyata iti uktaḥ sa sarvabandha vinirmuktaḥ śuddhena eva ātmanā avatiṣṭhate
translated: He who is said to be accomplished here is freed from all bondage and abides with pure self alone.

original: pūrvatra tu andho bhavati api roditi iva vināśameva apīto bhavati iti ca avasthātraya kaluṣitena ātmana iti ayaṃ viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvatra tu andhaḥ bhavati api roditi iva vināśam eva api itas bhavati iti ca avasthā traya kaluṣitena ātmanaḥ iti ayam viśeṣaḥ
translated: But in the previous case, he is blind, he cries as if, and he goes to destruction as if, with a self defiled by the three states. This is the difference.

original: kathaṃ punaḥ avagamyate muktaḥ ayam idānīṃ bhavati iti pratijñānāt ityāha /
analyzed: katham punar avagamyate muktaḥ ayam idānīm bhavati iti pratijñānāt iti āha
translated: How, then, is it known that he is now liberated? Because of the promise, he says.

original: tathā hi 'etaṃ tveva te bhūyo 'nuvyākhyāsyāmi' chā / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: tathā hi etam tu eva te bhūyas nuvyākhyāsyāmi chā
translated: For thus: 'But I will explain this to you again' (Ch. U. 8. 7. 1),

original: iti avasthātraya doṣavihīnam ātmānaṃ vyākhyeyatvena pratijñāya 'aśarīraṃ vāva santaṃ na priyāpriye spṛśataḥ chā / / /
analyzed: iti avasthā traya doṣa vihīnam ātmānam vyākhyeya tvena pratijñāya aśarīram vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśataḥ
translated: having promised to explain the self free from the faults of the three states as something to be explained, and having introduced it thus: 'Truly, when he is bodiless, neither pleasure nor pain touches him' (Ch. U. 8. 11. 1),

original: iti ca upanyasya 'svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyate sa uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ' chā / / /🔽iti ca upasaṃharati /
analyzed: iti ca upanyasya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate saḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ chā 🔽iti ca upasaṃharati
translated: he concludes thus: 'That supreme person is accomplished in his own form' (Ch. U. 8. 12. 3).

original: tathā ākhyāyika upakrame api 'ya ātmāpahatapāpmā' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā ākhyāyike upakrame api yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā chā
translated: And in the beginning of the narrative also, 'That Self which is free from evil' (Ch. 8.7.1).🔽🔽

original: ityādi mukta ātmaviṣayam eva pratijñānam /
analyzed: ityādi muktaḥ ātma viṣayam eva pratijñānam
translated: And even in the beginning of the narrative, the promise is about the liberated Self alone: 'That Self which is free from evil...' etc.

original: phalatvaprasiddhiḥ api mokṣasya bandhanivṛttimātra apekṣā na apūrva upajanana apekṣā /
analyzed: phala tva prasiddhiḥ api mokṣasya bandha nivṛttimātra apekṣā na apūrva upajanana apekṣā
translated: And the well-known result of liberation is merely the cessation of bondage, not the production of something new.

original: yat api abhiniṣpadyata iti utpattiparyāyatvaṃ tat api pūrva avasthāpekṣaṃ yathā roganivṛttau arogaḥabhiniṣpadyata iti tadvat /
analyzed: yat api abhiniṣpadyate iti utpatti paryāya tvam tat api pūrva avasthā apekṣam yathā roga nivṛttau arogaḥ abhiniṣpadyate iti tadvat
translated: And the statement 'it becomes manifest' is a synonym for origination, which is dependent on a previous state, just as when a disease is cured, one becomes manifest as healthy.

original: tasmāt adoṣaḥ // //
analyzed: tasmāt adoṣaḥ
translated: Therefore there is no fault.

original: ātmā prakaraṇāt / / / /
analyzed: ātmā prakaraṇāt
translated: The Self, because of the context.

original: kathaṃ punaḥ mukta iti ucyate yāvatā 'paraṃ jyotirupasaṃpadya' chā / / /
analyzed: katham punar muktaḥ iti ucyate yāvatā param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya chā
translated: But how is it said that one is liberated, since it is heard that 'having attained the supreme light' etc.

original: iti kāryagocaram eva enaṃ śrāvayati /
analyzed: iti kārya gocaram eva enam śrāvayati
translated: It makes one hear about it as an effect.

original: jyotiḥśabdasya bhautike jyotiṣi rūḍhatvāt /
analyzed: jyotiḥ śabdasya bhautike jyotiṣi rūḍha tvāt
translated: Because the word 'light' is well-known for material light.

original: na ca anativṛtto vikāraviṣayāt kaścit mukto bhavitum arhati /
analyzed: na ca an ativṛttaḥ vikāra viṣayāt kaścid muktaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: And one who has not transcended the sphere of modification cannot be liberated.

original: vikārasya ārtatvaprasiddheḥ iti /
analyzed: vikārasya ārta tva prasiddheḥ iti
translated: Because modification is known to be painful.

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: yata jyotiḥ śabdena āvedyate prakaraṇāt 'ya ātmāpahatapāpmā vijaro vimṛtyuḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: yata jyotiḥ śabdena āvedyate prakaraṇāt yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā vijaraḥ vimṛtyuḥ chā
translated: Because the Self is indicated by the word 'light' due to the context: 'That Self which is free from evil, free from old age, free from death...' etc.

original: iti hi prakṛte parasmin ātmani na akasmāt bhautikaṃ jyotiḥ śakyaṃ grahītum /
analyzed: iti hi prakṛte parasmin ātmani na akasmāt bhautikam jyotiḥ śakyam grahītum
translated: For thus, in the highest Self which is the topic, it is not possible to take up the elemental light all of a sudden.

original: prakṛtahāna aprakṛtaprakriyā prasaṅgāt /
analyzed: prakṛta hāna aprakṛta prakriyā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would involve the abandoning of the topic and the introduction of a new one.

original: jyotiḥśabdaḥ tu ātmani api dṛśyate 'taddevā jyotiṣaṃ jyotiḥ bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: jyotiḥ śabdaḥ tu ātmani api dṛśyate tat devāḥ jyotiṣam jyotiḥ iti
translated: But the word light is also seen to be used in reference to the Self, as in the passage, 'The gods who are in the light of the light' (Tai. 2.1).

original: prapañcitaṃ caitat'bra / sū / / / ityatra // //
analyzed: prapañcitam ca etat bra sū iti atra
translated: And this has been discussed in the Brahmasutra (3.2.1).

original: avibhāgena dṛṣṭatva adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: avibhāgena dṛṣṭa tva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on being seen without distinction. Sutra.

original: avibhāgena dṛṣṭatvāt / / / /
analyzed: avibhāgena dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because of being seen without distinction.

original: paraṃ jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate yaḥ sa kiṃ parasmāt ātmanaḥ pṛthageva bhavati uta avibhāgena eva avatiṣṭhata vīkṣāyām
analyzed: param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate yaḥ sa kim parasmāt ātmanaḥ pṛthak eva bhavati uta avibhāgena eva avatiṣṭhata vīkṣāyām  /
translated: One who, having attained the highest light, manifests in his own form, is he separate from the highest Self or does he abide without distinction? In this doubt,

original: sa 'tatra paryeti' / /🔽iti adhikaraṇa adhikartavya nirdeśāt jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya chā / / /
analyzed: sa tatra paryeti  iti adhikaraṇa adhikartavya nirdeśāt jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya chā
translated: 'There he moves about' (Tai. 2.7).

original: iti ca kartṛkarmanirdeśāt bhedena eva avasthānam iti yasya matiḥ taṃ vyutpādayati avibhakta eva pareṇa ātmanā muktaḥ avatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: iti ca kartṛ karma nirdeśāt bhedena eva avasthānam iti yasya matiḥ tam vyutpādayati avibhaktaḥ eva pareṇa ātmanā muktaḥ avatiṣṭhate
translated: This shows that the one who attains the light is the agent and object, so he abides separately. He who thinks this, he is instructed: The liberated one abides without distinction from the highest Self.

original: kutaḥ dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: kutas dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Why? Because of being seen thus.

original: tathā hi 'tattvamasi' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā hi tat tvam asi chā
translated: 'That thou art' (Ch. 6.8.7).

original: 'ahaṃ brahmāsmi' bṛ / / /🔽'yatra nānyatpaśyati' chā / / /
analyzed: aham brahma asmi bṛ  yatra na anyat paśyati chā
translated: 1. 'I am Brahman' (Br. Up. 4.5.6).🔽2. 'Where one sees nothing else' (Ch. Up. 7.24.1).

original: 'na tu taddvitīyamasti tato 'nyadvibhaktaṃ yatpaśyet' bṛ / / /
analyzed: na tu tat dvitīyam asti tatas yat paśyet
translated: 3. 'But there is no second there, nothing else distinct that one could see' (Br. Up. 4.3.22).

original: iti evamādīni vākyāni avibhāgena eva paramātmānaṃ darśayanti /
analyzed: iti evamādīni vākyāni avibhāgena eva paramātmānam darśayanti
translated: These and other passages show the supreme Self as undivided.

original: yathādarśanam eva ca phalaṃ yuktaṃ tatkratu nyāyāt /
analyzed: yathādarśanam eva ca phalam yuktam tad kratu nyāyāt
translated: And the result is proper just as it is seen, by the principle of the will of that (Self).

original: 'yathodakaṃ śuddhe śuddhamāsiktaṃ tādṛgeva bhavati /
analyzed: yathā udakam śuddhe śuddham āsiktam tādṛś eva bhavati
translated: 'Just as pure water poured into pure water becomes the same,

original: evaṃ muneḥ vijānata ātmā bhavati gautama' ka / /
analyzed: evam muneḥ vijānataḥ ātmā bhavati gautama ka
translated: so does the Self of the sage become, O Gautama' (Ch. Up. 7.24.1).

original: iti ca evamādīni muktasvarūpanirūpaṇaparāṇi vākyāni avibhāgameva darśayanti /
analyzed: iti ca evamādīni mukta svarūpa nirūpaṇa parāṇi vākyāni avibhāgam eva darśayanti
translated: And passages such as these, which are devoted to describing the nature of the liberated one, show (the Self) as undivided.

original: nadī samudrādi nidarśanāni ca /
analyzed: nadī samudra ādi nidarśanāni ca
translated: And there are similes such as the river and the ocean.

original: bhedanirdeśaḥ tu abhede api upacaryate /
analyzed: bheda nirdeśaḥ tu abhede api upacaryate
translated: But the teaching of difference is used even where there is non-difference.

original: 'sa bhagavaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti sve mahimni' chā / / /
analyzed: sa bhagavaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti sve mahimni chā
translated: 'In what is he established, O revered one?' 'In his own greatness' (Ch. Up. 7.24.1).

original: iti 'ātmaratirātmakrīḍaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: iti ātma ratiḥ ātma krīḍaḥ chā
translated: 'Delighting in the Self, playing with the Self' (Ch. Up. 7.24.1).

original: iti ca evamādidarśanāt // //
analyzed: iti ca evamādi darśanāt
translated: And because of the seeing of such things,

original: brāhma adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: brāhma adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on Brahman. Sutra.

original: brāhmeṇa jaiminir upanyāsādibhyaḥ / / / /
analyzed: brāhmeṇa jaiminiḥ upanyāsa ādibhyaḥ  /
translated: Jaimini, by the Brahman, from the beginning of the Upanishads, etc.

original: sthitam etat 'svena rūpeṇa'chā / / /
analyzed: sthitam etat svena rūpeṇa achā
translated: This has been established: 'In its own form' (Ch. Up. 8.1.1).

original: iti atra ātmamātrarūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata na āgantukena apararūpeṇa iti /
analyzed: iti atra ātma mātra rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata na āgantukena apara rūpeṇa iti
translated: Thus, it is established in its own form alone, not in an adventitious other form.

original: adhunā tu tat viśeṣabubhutsāyām abhidhīyate svam asya rūpaṃ brāhmam apahatapāpmatvādi
analyzed: adhunā tu tat viśeṣa bubhutsāyām abhidhīyate svam asya rūpam brāhmam apahata pāpma tva ādi
translated: But now, when there is a desire to know that distinction, it is said that its own form is Brahman, beginning with being free from evil,

original: satyasaṃkalpatva avasānaṃ tathā sarvajñatvaṃ sarveśvaratvaṃ ca tena svarūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata
analyzed: satya saṃkalpa tva avasānam tathā sarvajña tvam sarva īśvara tvam ca tena svarūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyata
translated: ending with having true desires and intentions, and likewise being omniscient and the lord of all. It is established in that form.

original: iti jaiminiḥ ācāryo manyate /
analyzed: iti jaiminiḥ ācāryaḥ manyate
translated: Thus the teacher Jaimini thinks.

original: kutaḥ upanyāsādibhyaḥ tathātva avagamāt /🔽tathā hi 'ya ātmāpahatapāpmā' chā / / /🔽ityādinā 'satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: kutas upanyāsa ādibhyaḥ tathātva avagamāt  tathā hi yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā chā  ityādinā satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ chā
translated: Why? Because the nature is understood from the introduction and so on.🔽For thus, by the introduction beginning with 'The Self which is free from evil'

original: iti evam antena upanyāsena evam ātmakatām ātmano bodhayati /
analyzed: iti evam antena upanyāsena evam ātmaka tām ātmanaḥ bodhayati
translated: and ending with 'having true desires and intentions', it makes known the nature of the Self in this way.

original: tathā 'sa tatra paryeti jakṣankrīḍanramamāṇaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā sa tatra paryeti jakṣan krīḍan ramamāṇaḥ chā
translated: Similarly, by 'He moves about there, eating, playing, and enjoying himself',

original: iti aiśvaryarūpam āvedayati /
analyzed: iti aiśvarya rūpam āvedayati
translated: it declares the form of lordship.

original: 'tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati' chā / / / iti ca /
analyzed: tasya sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati chā iti ca
translated: And 'He has freedom of action in all worlds'

original: 'sarvajñaḥ sarveśvaraḥ' ityādi vyapadeśāḥ ca evam upapannā bhaviṣyanti iti // //
analyzed: sarvajñaḥ sarveśvaraḥ ityādi vyapadeśāḥ ca evam upapannā bhaviṣyanti iti  /
translated: and the designations 'omniscient', 'lord of all', and so on will be justified in this way.

original: cititanmātreṇa tadātmakatvād ity auḍulomiḥ / / / /
analyzed: citi tanmātreṇa tad ātmaka tvāt iti auḍulomiḥ
translated: Audūlaomi [says that Brahman is manifested] by mere intelligence, because that is its nature.

original: yadyapi apahapāpmatvādayobhedena eva dharmā nirdiśyante tathā api śabdavikalpajā eva ete /
analyzed: yadi api apaha pāpma tva ādayaḥ bhedena eva dharmāḥ nirdiśyante tathā api śabda vikalpa jāḥ eva ete
translated: Even though the qualities such as being free from sin are described as distinct, they are merely verbal distinctions.

original: pāpmādinivṛttimātraṃ hi tatra gamyate /
analyzed: pāpma ādi nivṛtti mātram hi tatra gamyate
translated: For only the cessation of sin etc. is understood there.

original: caitanyameva tu asya ātmanaḥ svarūpam iti tanmātreṇa svarūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ yuktā /
analyzed: caitanyam eva tu asya ātmanaḥ svarūpam iti tanmātreṇa svarūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ yuktā
translated: But consciousness alone is the nature of this Self. Therefore, its manifestation by that alone, by its own nature, is proper.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ 'evaṃ vā are 'yamātmānantaro 'bāhyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ prajñānaghana eva' bṛ / / /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ evam vai are yam ātmā anantaraḥ bāhyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ prajñāna ghanaḥ eva
translated: And thus the Śruti passage, Verily, O dear one, this Self is to be seen, to be heard about, to be thought, to be reflected upon (Br. 3.4.1),

original: iti evañjātīyakā anugṛhītā bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: iti evañjātīyakā anugṛhītā bhaviṣyati
translated: will be supported in this way.

original: satyakāmatvādayaḥ tu yadi api vastusvarūpeṇa eva dharmā ucyante satyāḥ kāmā asya iti /
analyzed: satya kāma tva ādayaḥ tu yadi api vastu svarūpeṇa eva dharmāḥ ucyante satyāḥ kāmāḥ asya iti
translated: As for the qualities such as having true desires, even though they are described as qualities of the real nature of the entity, as in He has true desires,

original: tathā api upādhisaṃbandha adhīnatvāt teṣāṃ na caitanyavat svarūpasaṃbhavaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api upādhi saṃbandha adhīna tvāt teṣām na caitanya vat svarūpa saṃbhavaḥ
translated: still, because they depend on the relation with limiting adjuncts, they cannot naturally exist like consciousness.

original: aneka ākāratvapratiṣedāt /
analyzed: anekaḥ ākāra tva pratiṣedāt
translated: Because the existence of multiple forms is denied.

original: pratiṣiddhaṃ hi brahmaṇaḥ aneka ākāratvam 'na sthānato 'pi parasyobhayaliṅgam' bra /sū / / / ityatra /
analyzed: pratiṣiddham hi brahmaṇaḥ aneka ākāra tvam na parasya ubhaya liṅgam iti atra
translated: For the existence of multiple forms of Brahman has been denied at Nor is there duality in It on account of place (Br. 3.8.9).

original: ata eva ca jakṣaṇādi saṃkīrtanam api duḥkha abhāvamātra abhiprāyaṃ stutyartham ātmaratiḥ ityādivat /
analyzed: atas eva ca jakṣaṇa ādi saṃkīrtanam api duḥkha abhāva mātra abhiprāyam stuti artham ātma ratiḥ ityādi vat
translated: For this very reason, the mention of protection etc. also is meant to indicate mere absence of suffering, for the purpose of praise, like in the statement he delights in the self.

original: na hi mukhyāni eva ratikrīḍāmithunāni ātmani śakyante varṇayituṃ dvitīya viṣayatvāt teṣām /
analyzed: na hi mukhyāni eva rati krīḍā mithunāni ātmani śakyante varṇayitum dvitīya viṣaya tvāt teṣām
translated: For it is not possible to describe the primary activities of delight, play, and sexual union in relation to the self, because they have a second object.

original: tasmāt nirasta aśeṣaprapañcena prasannena avyapadeśyena bodhātmanā abhiniṣpadyata iti auḍulomiḥ ācāryo manyate // //
analyzed: tasmāt nirasta aśeṣa prapañcena prasannena avyapadeśyena bodha ātmanā abhiniṣpadyate iti auḍulomiḥ ācāryaḥ manyate  /
translated: Therefore, Ācārya Audūlaomi thinks that one becomes manifest by the self, which is the nature of consciousness, which is free from all conceptual elaborations, which is pleased, and which is inexpressible.

original: evam apy upanyāsāt pūrvabhāvād avirodhaṃ bādarāyaṇaḥ / / / /🔽evam api pāramārthika caitanyamātrasvarūpa abhyupagame api vyavahāra apekṣayā pūrvasya🔽api upanyāsādibhyaḥ avagatasya brāhmasya aiśvaryarūpasya apratyayākhyānāt avirodhaṃ
analyzed: evam api upanyāsāt pūrva bhāvāt avirodham bādarāyaṇaḥ  / evam api pāramārthika caitanya mātra svarūpa abhyupagame api vyavahāra apekṣayā pūrvasya  api upanyāsa ādibhyaḥ avagatasya brāhmasya aiśvarya rūpasya a pratyaya ākhyānāt avirodham
translated: Even so, Bādarāyaṇa thinks there is no contradiction due to the prior existence indicated by the statement.

original: bādarāyaṇa ācāryo manyate // //🔽saṃkalpa adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: bādarāyaṇaḥ ācāryaḥ manyate  saṃkalpa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Even so, even when the nature of Brahman is accepted as being only the ultimate consciousness, Bādarāyaṇa Ācārya thinks there is no contradiction due to the non-denial of the form of lordship of Brahman, which is understood from the statement etc. in relation to conventional usage.🔽The section on volition. Sutra.

original: saṃkalpād eva tu tacchruteḥ / / / /
analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva tu tad śruteḥ
translated: But due to the mention of volition alone, it is so.

original: hārdavidyāyāṃ śrūyate 'sa yadi pitṛlokakāmo bhavati saṃkalpādevāsya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti' chā / / / ityādi /
analyzed: hārdavidyāyām śrūyate sa yadi pitṛ loka kāmaḥ bhavati saṃkalpāt eva asya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti chā ityādi
translated: In the science of the heart it is heard: 'If he desires the world of the fathers, by mere will his fathers rise up for him' (Ch. U. 8. 15. 1), and so on.

original: tatra saṃśayaḥ kiṃ saṃkalpa eva kevalaḥ pitrādisamutthāne hetuḥ uta nimittāntara sahita iti /
analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim saṃkalpaḥ eva kevalaḥ pitṛ ādi samutthāne hetuḥ uta nimitta antara sahitaḥ iti
translated: There is doubt: Is mere will alone the cause of the rising of the fathers and so on, or is it accompanied by some other cause?

original: tatra sati api saṃkalpādeva iti śravaṇe lokavat nimittāntara apekṣatā yuktā /
analyzed: tatra sati api saṃkalpādeva iti śravaṇe loka vat nimitta antara apekṣa tā yuktā
translated: There, even though there is the statement 'by mere will', it is proper that it should require some other cause, as in the world.

original: yathā loke asmadādīnāṃ saṃkalpāt gamanādibhyaḥ ca hetubhyaḥ pitrādi saṃpattiḥ bhavati evaṃ muktasya api syāt /
analyzed: yathā loke asmat ādīnām saṃkalpāt gamana ādibhyaḥ ca hetubhyaḥ pitṛ ādi saṃpattiḥ bhavati evam muktasya api syāt
translated: Just as for us in the world, the attainment of fathers and so on is by will and other causes such as going, so also for the liberated one.

original: evaṃ dṛṣṭaviparītaṃ na kalpitaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: evam dṛṣṭa viparītam na kalpitam bhaviṣyati
translated: Thus it will not be imagined as contrary to what is seen.

original: saṃkalpādeva iti tu rājña iva saṃkalpitārthasiddhikarīṃ sādhanāntarasāmagrīṃ sulabhām apekṣya ucyate /
analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva iti tu rājñaḥ iva saṃkalpita artha siddhi karīm sādhana antara sāmagrīm sulabhām apekṣya ucyate
translated: But 'by mere will' is said with reference to the availability of other means that accomplish the desired object, like a king.

original: na ca saṃkalpamātrasam utthānāḥ pitrādayo manorathāvijṛmbhitavat calatvāt puṣkalaṃ bhogaṃ samarpayituṃ paryāptāḥ syuḥ iti /
analyzed: na ca saṃkalpa mātra sam utthānāḥ pitṛ ādayaḥ manoratha avijṛmbhita vat cala tvāt puṣkalam bhogam samarpayitum paryāptāḥ syuḥ iti
translated: And those fathers and so on who rise by mere will, being unsteady like the manifestation of a wish, would not be sufficient to bestow abundant enjoyment.

original: evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ saṃkalpādeva tu kevalāt pitrādisamutthānam iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ saṃkalpāt eva tu kevalāt pitṛ ādi samutthānam iti
translated: To this we reply: But the origination of the ancestors etc. is only from mere volition.

original: kutaḥ tat śruteḥ /
analyzed: kutas tat śruteḥ
translated: Why? Because of the Vedic text.

original: 'saṃkalpādevāsya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti' chā / / /
analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva asya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti chā
translated: For there is a Vedic text: His ancestors rise up from mere volition (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.10.5).

original: ityādikā hi śrutiḥ nimittāntara apekṣāyāṃ pīḍyeta /
analyzed: ityādikā hi śrutiḥ nimitta antara apekṣāyām pīḍyeta
translated: If it required another cause, that text would be contradicted.

original: nimittāntaram api tu yadi saṃkalpa anuvidhāyi eva syāt bhavatu na tu prayatnāntarasaṃpādyaṃ nimittāntaram iti iṣyate /
analyzed: nimitta antaram api tu yadi saṃkalpa anuvidhāyi eva syāt bhavatu na tu prayatna antara saṃpādyam nimitta antaram iti iṣyate
translated: But if that other cause also were to conform to volition, let it be so. But it is not accepted that the other cause is accomplished by another effort.

original: prāk tat saṃpatteḥ vandhyasaṃkalpatva prasaṅgāt /
analyzed: prāk tat saṃpatteḥ vandhyasaṃkalpatva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because before its accomplishment, volition would be fruitless.

original: na ca śruti avagamye arthe lokavat iti sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ kramate /
analyzed: na ca śruti avagamye arthe loka vat iti sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam kramate
translated: And in a matter known from the Veda, a general principle based on what is seen in the world does not apply.

original: saṃkalpabalāt eva ca eṣāṃ yāvat prayojanaṃ sthairya upapattiḥ / prākṛtasaṃkalpavilakṣaṇatvāt muktasaṃkalpasya // //
analyzed: saṃkalpa balāt eva ca eṣām yāvat prayojanam sthairya upapattiḥ prākṛta saṃkalpa vilakṣaṇa tvāt mukta saṃkalpasya
translated: And the stability of these ancestors for as long as necessary is possible only by the power of volition, because the volition of the liberated one is different from ordinary volition.

original: ata eva cānanyādhipatiḥ / / / /
analyzed: atas eva ca an anya adhipatiḥ
translated: And for this very reason, he is not subject to another's control.

original: ata eva ca avandhyasaṃkalpatvāt ananya adhipatiḥ vidvān bhavati na asya anyaḥ adhipatiḥ bhavati ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva ca avandhya saṃkalpa tvāt ananya adhipatiḥ vidvān bhavati na asya anyaḥ adhipatiḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: And for this very reason, because his volition is not fruitless, the knower is not subject to another's control. The meaning is that he is not under the control of another.

original: na hi prākṛto api saṃkalpayan anyasvāmikatvam ātmanaḥ satyāṃ gatau saṃkalpayati /
analyzed: na hi prākṛtaḥ api saṃkalpayan anya svāmika tvam ātmanaḥ satyām gatau saṃkalpayati
translated: For even an ordinary man, when he imagines, does not imagine himself to be under the ownership of another, if there is a way to avoid it.

original: śrutiḥ ca etat darśayati 'atha ya ihātmānamanuvidya vrajantyeśca satyānkāmāṃsteṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati' chā / / / iti //
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca etat darśayati atha ye iha ātmānam anuvidya vrajantyeḥ ca satyān kāmān teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati chā iti
translated: And the Śruti shows this: 'Then those who, having discovered the Self here, go to the world of Brahman, for them there is freedom to go as they wish in all the worlds' (Chānd. 7.25.2).

original: abhāva adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: abhāva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on non-existence. Sutra.

original: abhāvaṃ bādarir āha hy evam / / / /
analyzed: abhāvam bādariḥ āha hi evam
translated: Badari says there is non-existence, for it is so.

original: 'saṃkalpādevāsya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti' chā / / /
analyzed: saṃkalpāt eva asya pitaraḥ samuttiṣṭhanti chā
translated: 'By mere resolve, his ancestors rise up' (Chānd. 8.8.7).

original: ityādi śruteḥ manaḥ tāvat saṃkalpasādhanaṃ siddham /
analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ manaḥ tāvat saṃkalpa sādhanam siddham
translated: Thus, the mind is established as the means of accomplishing resolve.

original: śarīra indriyāṇi punaḥ prāpta aiśvaryasya viduṣaḥ santi na vā santi iti samīkṣyate /
analyzed: śarīra indriyāṇi punar prāpta aiśvaryasya viduṣaḥ santi na vā santi iti samīkṣyate
translated: Now, whether the body and senses of the wise one who has attained lordship exist or not is considered.

original: tatra bādariḥ tāvat ācāryaḥ śarīrasya indriyāṇāṃ ca abhāvaṃ mahīyamānasya viduṣo manyate /
analyzed: tatra bādariḥ tāvat ācāryaḥ śarīrasya indriyāṇām ca abhāvam mahīyamānasya viduṣaḥ manyate
translated: To this, the teacher Badari thinks that for the exalted wise one, there is non-existence of the body and senses.

original: kasmāt /
analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: evaṃ hi āha āmnāyaḥ 'manasaitānkāmānpaśyanramate' chā / / /
analyzed: evam hi āha āmnāyaḥ manasā etān kāmān paśyan ramate chā
translated: For thus the Veda declares: 'Beholding these desires with the mind, he delights' (Chānd. 8.12.5).

original: 'ya ete brahmaloke' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: ye ete brahma loke chā iti
translated: 'Those who are in the world of Brahman' (Chānd. 8.3.2).

original: yadi manasā śarīra indriyāṇāṃ mokṣe // //
analyzed: yadi manasā śarīre indriyāṇām mokṣe
translated: If by the mind, the body and senses are liberated in deep sleep,

original: bhāvaṃ jaiminir vikalpāmananāt / / / /
analyzed: bhāvam jaiminiḥ vikalpa āmananāt
translated: Jaimini thinks that the liberated soul has a body, because of the option of the mind.

original: jaiminiḥ tu ācāryo manovat śarīrasya api sendriyasya bhāvaṃ muktaṃ prati manyate /
analyzed: jaiminiḥ tu ācāryaḥ manaḥ vat śarīrasya api sa indriyasya bhāvam muktam prati manyate
translated: But the teacher Jaimini thinks that the liberated soul has a body along with the senses,

original: yataḥ 'sa ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati'chā / / /
analyzed: yatas saḥ ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati ichā
translated: because it is stated in such passages as He becomes one, he becomes three (Ch. Up. 7.26.2),

original: ityādinā anekadhā abhāvavikalpam āmananti /
analyzed: ityādinā anekadhā abhāva vikalpam āmananti
translated: that there is an option of becoming in many ways.

original: na hi anekavidhatā vinā śarīrabhedena āñjasī syāt /
analyzed: na hi anekavidha tā vinā śarīrabhedena āñjasī syāt
translated: For the state of being in many ways would not be natural without a division of the body.

original: yadi api nirguṇāyāṃ bhūmavidyāyām ayam anekadhā abhāvavikalpaḥ paṭhyate tathā api
analyzed: yadi api nirguṇāyām bhūma vidyāyām ayam anekadhā abhāva vikalpaḥ paṭhyate tathā api
translated: Even though this option of becoming in many ways is stated in the Nirguṇa Bhūman knowledge,

original: vidyamānameva idaṃ saguṇāvasthāyām aiśvaryaṃ bhūmavidyā stutaye saṃkīrtyata iti ataḥ
analyzed: vidyamānam eva idam saguṇa avasthāyām aiśvaryam bhūmavidyā stutaye saṃkīrtyate iti atas
translated: nevertheless, this lordship which exists in the Saguṇa state is glorified for the praise of the Bhūman knowledge. Therefore,

original: saguṇavidyāphalabhāvena upatiṣṭhata iti // //
analyzed: saguṇa vidyā phala bhāvena upatiṣṭhate iti
translated: it is presented as the fruit of the Saguṇa knowledge.

original: ucyate
analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: dvādaśāhavad ubhayavidhaṃ bādarāyaṇo 'taḥ / / / /
analyzed: dvādaśa aha vat ubhayavidham   /
translated: Bādarāyaṇa thinks that it is of both kinds, like the Dvādaśāha.

original: bādarāyaṇaḥ punaḥ ācāryaḥ ata eva ubhayaliṅgaśrutidarśanāt ubhayavidhatvaṃ sādhu manyate yadā saśarīratāṃ saṃkalpayati tadā saśarīro bhavati
analyzed: bādarāyaṇaḥ punar ācāryaḥ atas eva ubhaya liṅga śruti darśanāt ubhayavidha tvam sādhu manyate yadā sa śarīra tām saṃkalpayati tadā sa śarīraḥ bhavati  /
translated: But the teacher Bādarāyaṇa thinks that it is rightly of both kinds, because of the seeing of the Śruti texts indicating both, when it wills to have a body, then it becomes with a body,

original: yadā tu aśarīratāṃ tadā aśarīra iti /
analyzed: yadā tu aśarīra tām tadā aśarīraḥ iti
translated: But when there is no body, then he is bodiless.

original: satyasaṃkalpatvāt /
analyzed: satya saṃkalpa tvāt
translated: Because of the truth of his resolve.

original: saṃkalpa vaicitryāt ca /🔽dvādaśa ahavat /
analyzed: saṃkalpa vaicitryāt ca  dvādaśa ahavat
translated: And because of the variety of resolves.🔽Like the twelve-day sacrifice.

original: yathā dvādaśa ahaḥsatram ahīnaḥ ca bhavati /🔽ubhayaliṅga śrutidarśanāt evam idam api iti // //
analyzed: yathā dvādaśa ahaḥsatram ahīnaḥ ca bhavati  ubhaya liṅga śruti darśanāt evam idam api iti  /
translated: Just as the twelve-day sacrifice is both an Ahina and a Sattra,

original: tanvabhāve sandhyavad upapatteḥ / / / /🔽yadā tanoḥ sendriyasya śarīrasya abhāvaḥ tadā yathā saṃdhye sthāne śarīra indriyaviṣayeṣu
analyzed: tanu abhāve sandhyā vat upapatteḥ  yadā tanoḥ sa indriyasya śarīrasya abhāvaḥ tadā yathā saṃdhye sthāne śarīra indriya viṣayeṣu
translated: because of the occurrence of both types of indications in the scriptures, so is this case also.🔽When there is no body, like in the twilight, because it is possible.

original: avidyamāneṣu api upalabdhimātrā eva pitrādikāmā bhavati evaṃ mokṣe api syuḥ evaṃ
analyzed: a vidyamāneṣu api upalabdhi mātrā eva pitṛ ādi kāmāḥ bhavati evam mokṣe api syuḥ evam
translated: When there is no body with senses, then just as in the twilight, even though the body, senses and objects are absent, the desires for father etc. are still experienced, so it would be in liberation also.

original: hi etat upapadyate // //
analyzed: hi etat upapadyate  /
translated: For in this way it is possible.

original: bhāve jāgradvat / / / /
analyzed: bhāve jāgrat vat
translated: When there is, like in the waking state.

original: bhāve punaḥ tanoḥ yathā jāgarite vidyamānā eva pitrādikāmā bhavanti evaṃ muktasya api upapadyate // //
analyzed: bhāve punar tanoḥ yathā jāgarite vidyamānāḥ eva pitṛ ādi kāmāḥ bhavanti evam muktasya api upapadyate  /
translated: When there is a body, then just as the desires for father etc. are present in the waking state, so it is possible for the liberated one also.

original: pradīpa adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: pradīpa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the lamp. The verse.

original: pradīpavadāveśas tathā hi darśayati / / / /
analyzed: pradīpa vat āveśaḥ tathā hi darśayati
translated: The manifestation is like a lamp, because it is shown thus.

original: bhāvaṃ 'jaiminirvikalpāmananāt' bra /sū / / /
analyzed: bhāvam jaiminiḥ vikalpa āmananāt brasū
translated: Existence, 'Jaimini because of the absence of consideration' Brahmasutra.

original: iti atra saśarīratvaṃ muktasya uktam /
analyzed: iti atra sa śarīra tvam muktasya uktam
translated: Here, the existence of a body for the liberated one has been stated.

original: tatra tridhābhāvādiṣu anekaśarīrasarge kiṃ nirātmakāni śarīrāṇi dāruyantrāṇi iva sṛjyante kiṃ vā sātmakāni asmadādi śarīravat iti bhavati vīkṣā
analyzed: tatra tridhā bhāva ādiṣu aneka śarīra sarge kim nirātmakāni śarīrāṇi dāru yantrāṇi iva sṛjyante kim vā sātmakāni asmad ādi śarīra vat iti bhavati vīkṣā
translated: In this connection, when many bodies are created in the states of threefold existence, etc., are the bodies created devoid of souls, like wooden puppets, or are they endowed with souls, like our own bodies? This is the question.

original: tatra ca ātma manasoḥ bheda anupapatteḥ ekena śarīreṇa yogāt itarāṇi śarīrāṇi nirātmakāni iti /
analyzed: tatra ca ātma manasoḥ bheda anupapatteḥ ekena śarīreṇa yogāt itarāṇi śarīrāṇi nirātmakāni iti
translated: And since the distinction of soul and mind is not possible, because of the connection with one body, the other bodies are devoid of souls.

original: evaṃ prāpte pratipadyate pradīpavat āveśa iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte pratipadyate pradīpa vat āveśaḥ iti
translated: When this is the case, the author replies: The entry is like that of a lamp.

original: yathā pradīpa ekaḥ anekapradīpabhāvam āpadyate vikāraśaktiyogāt /
analyzed: yathā pradīpaḥ ekaḥ aneka pradīpa bhāvam āpadyate vikāra śakti yogāt
translated: Just as one lamp produces the state of many lamps due to the connection with the power of modification,

original: evam ekaḥ api san vidvāna aiśvaryayogāt anekabhāvam āpadya sarvāṇi śarīrāṇi āviśati /
analyzed: evam ekaḥ api san vidvāna aiśvaryayogāt anekabhāvam āpadya sarvāṇi śarīrāṇi āviśati
translated: in the same way, although one, the knower, by the connection with lordship, attains the state of many and enters all the bodies.

original: kutaḥ / tathā hi darśayati śāstram ekasya anekabhāvam 'sa ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati pañcadhā saptadhā navadhā' chā / / / ityādi /🔽na etat dāruyantra upamā abhyupagame avakalpate na api jīvāntarāveśe /
analyzed: kutas tathā hi darśayati śāstram ekasya aneka bhāvam saḥ ekadhā bhavati tridhā bhavati pañcadhā saptadhā navadhā chā  ityādi  na etat dāruyantra upamā abhyupagame avakalpate na api jīva antara āveśe
translated: Why? Because the scripture shows the state of one as many: He becomes one, he becomes three, he becomes five, he becomes seven, he becomes nine.🔽This is not possible if wooden puppets are accepted, nor if the entry of another individual soul is accepted.

original: na ca nirātmakānāṃ śarīrāṇāṃ pravṛttiḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na ca nirātmakānām śarīrāṇām pravṛttiḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And the activity of bodies devoid of souls is not possible.

original: yat tu ātma manasoḥ bheda anupapatteḥ anekaśarīrayoga asaṃbhava iti /
analyzed: yat tu ātma manasoḥ bheda anupapatteḥ aneka śarīra yoga asaṃbhavaḥ iti
translated: As for the objection that the distinction of the Self from the mind is impossible, and that therefore the connexion of the Self with more than one body is impossible, we reply as follows

original: na eṣa doṣaḥ /🔽ekamanonuvartini samanaskāni eva aparāṇi śarīrāṇi satyasaṃkalpatvāt srakṣyati /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  eka manaḥ nuvartini samanaskāni eva aparāṇi śarīrāṇi satya saṃkalpa tvāt srakṣyati
translated: This objection is without force🔽For the Self, whose will is ever fulfilled, will create other bodies, which will be endowed with minds, and will follow the one mind which is connected with the Self

original: sṛṣṭeṣu ca teṣu upādhibhedāt ātmanaḥ api bhedena adhiṣṭhātṛtvaṃ yokṣyate /
analyzed: sṛṣṭeṣu ca teṣu upādhi bhedāt ātmanaḥ api bhedena adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam yokṣyate
translated: And when those bodies have been created, the Self will be able to enter them, although really one only, on account of the difference of limiting adjuncts

original: eṣa eva ca yogaśāstreṣu yoginām anekaśarīraprayogakriyā // //🔽kathaṃ punaḥ muktasya anekaśarīra āveśādilakṣaṇam aiśvaryam abhyupagamyate yāvatā 'tatkena kaṃ vijānīyāt' bṛ / / /🔽'na tu taddvitīyamasti tato 'nyadvibhaktaṃ yadvijānīyāt' bṛ / / /🔽'salila eko draṣṭādvaito bhavati' bṛ / / /
analyzed: eṣaḥ eva ca yoga śāstreṣu yoginām aneka śarīra prayoga kriyā  katham punar muktasya aneka śarīra āveśa ādi lakṣaṇam aiśvaryam abhyupagamyate yāvatā tat kena kam vijānīyāt  na tu tat dvitīyam asti tatas yat vibhaktam yat vijānīyāt  salilaḥ ekaḥ draṣṭā advaitaḥ bhavati bṛ
translated: This very thing is taught in the Yogaśāstras, where it is said that the yogins can employ their bodies in various ways

original: iti ca evañjātīyakā śrutiḥ viśeṣavijñānaṃ vārayati ityata uttaraṃ paṭhati
analyzed: iti ca evañjātīyakā śrutiḥ viśeṣa vijñānam vārayati iti atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: But how can it be admitted that the released Self possesses the power of entering many bodies, and so on, seeing that scripture declares that the released Self is devoid of all plurality? Compare, for instance, Bṛ Up , , , Who could know him, who could declare him, by whom and through whom if he were known or declared this world is known and declared? Bṛ Up , , , There is no second whatever different from him which could be known Bṛ Up , , , He becomes one with the water, one, without a second Bṛ Up , , , and similar passages, which all deny the existence of any plurality of cognitions? To this question the next Sūtra replies

original: svāpyayasaṃpatyor anyatarāpekṣam āviṣkṛtaṃ hi / / / /
analyzed: sva apyaya saṃpatyoḥ anyatara apekṣam āviṣkṛtam hi
translated: The text quoted refers either to the state of deep sleep or to the state of final release, as is declared by Smṛti

original: svāpyayaḥ suṣuptam 'svamapīto bhavati tasmādenaṃ svapitītyācakṣate' chā / / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: sva apyayaḥ suṣuptam svam apītaḥ bhavati tasmāt enam svapiti iti ācakṣate chā iti śruteḥ
translated: Sleep is deep sleep, as stated in the Upanishad: He becomes united with his own Self. Therefore they call him 'sleeping'.

original: saṃpattiḥ kaivalyam /
analyzed: saṃpattiḥ kaivalyam
translated: Liberation is absolute separation.

original: 'brahmaiva sanbrahmāpyeti' bṛ / / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: brahma eva san brahma apyeti iti śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Upanishad: Having become Brahman, he goes to Brahman.

original: tayoḥ anyatarām avasthām apekṣya etat viśeṣasaṃjñābhāva vacanam /
analyzed: tayoḥ anyatarām avasthām apekṣya etat viśeṣa saṃjñā bhāva vacanam
translated: This statement about the absence of specific names is made with reference to one of those two states.

original: kvacit suṣupta avasthām apekṣya ucyate kvacit kaivalya avasthām /
analyzed: kvacid suṣupta avasthām apekṣya ucyate kvacid kaivalya avasthām
translated: In some cases it is said with reference to the state of deep sleep, in some cases with reference to the state of absolute separation.

original: katham avagamyate yataḥ tatra eva etat adhikāravaśāt āviṣkṛtam 'etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānu vinaśyati na pretya saṃjñāstīti' bṛ /
analyzed: katham avagamyate yatas tatra eva etat adhikāra vaśāt āviṣkṛtam etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tāni eva anu vinaśyati na pretya saṃjñā asti iti bṛhat
translated: How is this known? Because this is revealed there itself due to the context: Having arisen from these elements, he is destroyed along with them. After death there is no consciousness.

original: 'yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūt' bṛ / / /
analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt bṛ
translated: Where all this has become his Self alone.

original: 'yatra supto na kañcana kāmaṃ kāmayate na kañcana svapnaṃ paśyati' bṛ / / / / māṇḍū /
analyzed: yatra suptaḥ na kañcana kāmam kāmayate na kañcana svapnam paśyati
translated: Where, while sleeping, he does not desire any desire, does not see any dream.

original: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Thus it is known from such Upanishad passages.

original: saguṇavidyāvipāka avasthānaṃ tu etat svargādivat avasthāntaraṃ yatra etat aiśvaryam upavarṇyate /
analyzed: sa guṇa vidyā vipāka avasthānam tu etat svarga ādi vat avasthā antaram yatra etat aiśvaryam upavarṇyate
translated: But this state of abiding in the fruition of the knowledge with attributes is a different state like heaven, where this lordship is described.

original: tasmāt adoṣaḥ // //
analyzed: tasmāt adoṣaḥ
translated: Therefore there is no fault.

original: jagat vyāpāra adhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: jagat vyāpāra adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The topic of the operation of the world. Sūtra.

original: jagadvyāpāravarjaṃ prakaraṇād asaṃnihitatvāc ca / / / /
analyzed: jagat vyāpāra varjam prakaraṇāt asaṃnihita tvāt ca
translated: Apart from the operation of the world, because of the context and because of non-proximity.

original: ye saguṇabrahma upāsanāt saha eva manasā īśvarasāyujyaṃ vrajanti kiṃ teṣāṃ niravagraham aiśvaryaṃ bhavati āhosvit sāvagraham iti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: ye saguṇa brahma upāsanāt saha eva manasā īśvara sāyujyam vrajanti kim teṣām niravagraham aiśvaryam bhavati āhosvit sa avagraham iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: Those who, by the meditation on God with attributes, go to union with God along with the mind, does their lordship become unrestricted or restricted? This is the doubt.

original: kiṃ tāvat prāptam /
analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: niraṅ kuśameva eṣām aiśvaryaṃ bhavitum arhati 'āpnoti svārājyam' tai / / /
analyzed: niraṅ kuśam eva eṣām aiśvaryam bhavitum arhati āpnoti svārājyam
translated: Their lordship should be unrestricted. 'He attains self-sovereignty' (Tai. 3.12.9).

original: 'sarve 'smai devā balimāvahanti' tai / / /
analyzed: sarve smai devāḥ balim āvahanti taiḥ
translated: 'All the gods bring him tribute' (Tai. 2.1.1.1).

original: 'teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavati' chā / / / / / /
analyzed: teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavati chā
translated: 'He has freedom to go to all the worlds' (Chā. 8.15.1).

original: ityādi śrutibhya iti /
analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ iti
translated: Thus it is from the Vedic texts.

original: evaṃ prāpte paṭhati jagat vyāpāravarjam iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte paṭhati jagat vyāpāra varjam iti
translated: When this is the prima facie view, he recites 'apart from the operation of the world'.

original: jagat utpattyādi vyāpāraṃ varjayitvā anyat aṇimādi ātmakam aiśvaryaṃ muktānāṃ bhavitum arhati jagat vyāpāraḥ tu nityasiddhasya eva īśvarasya
analyzed: jagat utpatti ādi vyāpāram varjayitvā anyat aṇima ādi ātmakam aiśvaryam muktānām bhavitum arhati jagat vyāpāraḥ tu nitya siddhasya eva īśvarasya
translated: Apart from the operation of the creation etc. of the world, other lordship consisting of the powers like minuteness etc. should belong to the liberated souls. But the operation of the world belongs to God who is eternally existent.

original: kutaḥ tasya tatra prakṛtatvāt asaṃnihitatvāt ca itareṣām /
analyzed: kutas tasya tatra prakṛta tvāt asaṃnihita tvāt ca itareṣām
translated: Why? Because he is the subject there, and the others are not proximate.

original: para eva hi īśvaro jagat vyāpāre adhikṛtaḥ /
analyzed: paras eva hi īśvaraḥ jagat vyāpāre adhikṛtaḥ
translated: For the Lord alone is qualified to act in the creation of the world.

original: tam eva prakṛtya utpattyādi upadeśāt /
analyzed: tam eva prakṛtyā utpatti ādi upadeśāt
translated: Because the teaching of creation, etc. is with reference to Him alone.

original: nityaśabdanibandhanatvāt ca /
analyzed: nitya śabda nibandhana tvāt ca
translated: And because it is based on the eternal word.

original: tat anveṣaṇavijijñāsanapūrvakaṃ tu itareṣām aṇimādi aiśvaryaṃ śrūyate /
analyzed: tat anveṣaṇa vijijñāsana pūrvakam tu itareṣām aṇima ādi aiśvaryam śrūyate
translated: But the lordship of others, such as the power of becoming atomic, etc., is heard to be preceded by the search for and inquiry into that.

original: tena asaṃnihitāḥ te jagat vyāpāre /
analyzed: tena asaṃnihitāḥ te jagat vyāpāre
translated: Therefore, they are not present in the creation of the world.

original: samanaskatvāt eva ca eteṣām anaikamatye kasyacit sthiti abhiprāyaḥ kasyacit saṃhāra abhiprāya iti evaṃ virodhaḥ api kadācit syāt /
analyzed: samanaska tvāt eva ca eteṣām anaikamatye kasyacid sthiti abhiprāyaḥ kasyacid saṃhāra abhiprāya iti evam virodhaḥ api kadācid syāt
translated: And because they have minds, there might sometimes be contradiction, such as the intention of one to maintain and the intention of another to destroy.

original: atha kasyacit saṃkalpam anvayasya saṃkalpa iti avirodhaḥ samarthyeta tataḥ parameśvara ākūtatantratvam eva itareṣām iti vyavatiṣṭhate //
analyzed: atha kasyacid saṃkalpam anvayasya saṃkalpaḥ iti avirodhaḥ samarthyeta tatas parameśvaraḥ ākūta tantra tvam eva itareṣām iti vyavatiṣṭhate  /
translated: Or if it is argued that there is no contradiction because the intention of one follows the intention of another, then it is established that the others are dependent on the Supreme Lord's will.

original: pratyakṣopadeśād iti cen nādhikārikamaṇḍalasthokteḥ / / / /
analyzed: pratyakṣa upadeśāt iti ced na ādhikārika maṇḍala stha ukteḥ
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of the direct teaching, it is not so because it is stated in the circle of the qualified.

original: atha yat uktam 'āpnoti svārājyam' tai / / /
analyzed: atha yat uktam āpnoti svārājyam tai
translated: Now, what was said - He attains self-sovereignty (Taitt.

original: ityādi pratyakṣa upadeśāt niravagraham aiśvaryaṃ viduṣāṃ nyāyyam iti tatparihartavyam /
analyzed: ityādi pratyakṣa upadeśāt niravagraham aiśvaryam viduṣām nyāyyam iti tat parihartavyam
translated: Up. 2.1.1) etc. - that the lordship of the wise is reasonable without restraint because of the direct teaching, that should be refuted.

original: atra ucyate /
analyzed: atra ucyate
translated: To that, it is said.

original: na ayaṃ doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: ādhikārikamaṇḍalastha ukteḥ /
analyzed: ādhikārika maṇḍala sthaḥ ukteḥ
translated: Because it is said to be in the authoritative maṇḍala.

original: ādhikāriko yaḥ savitṛmaṇḍalādiṣu viśeṣa āyataneṣu avasthitaḥ para īśvaraḥ tadāyatta eva iyaṃ svārājyaprāptiḥ ucyate /
analyzed: ādhikārikaḥ yaḥ savitṛ maṇḍala ādiṣu viśeṣa āyataneṣu avasthitaḥ paraḥ īśvaraḥ tad āyattaḥ eva iyam svārājya prāptiḥ ucyate
translated: This attainment of self-sovereignty is said to be dependent only on that supreme Lord who is authoritative, who abides in the special abodes such as the maṇḍala of Savitr.

original: yatkāraṇam anantaram 'āpnoti manasaspatim' tai / / / ityāha /
analyzed: yatkāraṇam anantaram āpnoti manasaspatim tai iti āha
translated: For what reason? Because immediately after this, it is said: 'He attains the lord of the mind' (Tai. 2.1).

original: yo hi sarvamanasāṃ patiḥ pūrvasiddha īśvaraḥ taṃ prāpnoti iti etat uktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yaḥ hi sarva manasām patiḥ pūrva siddhaḥ īśvaraḥ tam prāpnoti iti etat uktam bhavati
translated: It is said that he attains that supreme Lord who is the lord of all minds and who is established from the beginning.

original: tat anusāreṇa eva ca anantaram 'vākpatiścakṣuṣpatiḥ śrotrapatirvijñānapatiśca bhavati' tai / / / ityāha /
analyzed: tat anusāreṇa eva ca anantaram vākpatiḥ cakṣuṣpatiḥ śrotra patiḥ vijñāna patiḥ ca bhavati tai iti āha
translated: And in accordance with that, immediately after this, it is said: 'He becomes the lord of speech, the lord of the eye, the lord of the ear, and the lord of consciousness' (Tai. 2.1).

original: evam anyatra api yathāsaṃbhavaṃ nityasiddha īśvara āyattam eva itareṣām aiśvaryaṃ yojayitavyam // //
analyzed: evam anyatra api yathāsaṃbhavam nitya siddhaḥ īśvaraḥ āyattam eva itareṣām aiśvaryam yojayitavyam  /
translated: Thus, in other places also, the sovereignty of the others should be connected to the eternally established Lord, as far as possible.

original: vikārāvarti ca tathā hi sthitim āha / / / /
analyzed: vikāra āvarti ca tathā hi sthitim āha
translated: And it is said that the form of the supreme Lord, which is eternally liberated, abides in that way, even in the transformations.

original: vikārāvartyapi ca nityamuktaṃ pārameśvaraṃ rūpaṃ na kevalaṃ vikāramātragocaraṃ savitṛmaṇḍalādi adhiṣṭhānam /
analyzed: vikāra āvarti api ca nityam uktam pārameśvaram rūpam na kevalam vikāra mātra gocaram savitṛ maṇḍala ādi adhiṣṭhānam
translated: And even in the transformations, the form of the supreme Lord, which is eternally liberated, is not merely within the range of the transformations, but is the basis such as the maṇḍala of Savitr.

original: tathā hi asya dvirūpāṃ sthitim āha āmnāyaḥ 'tāvānasya mahimā tato jyāyāṃśca puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi asya dvirūpām sthitim āha āmnāyaḥ tāvān asya mahimā tatas jyāyān ca puruṣaḥ
translated: For thus the Veda declares its twofold nature: 'His greatness is so great, and he is greater than that.

original: pādo 'sya sarvā bhūtāni /
analyzed: pādaḥ sya sarvā bhūtāni
translated: One foot of him are all beings.

original: tripādasyāmṛtaṃ divi' chā / / /
analyzed: tri pādasya amṛtam divi chā
translated: Three feet of him are the immortal in heaven.' (Śat. Br.

original: iti evamādiḥ /
analyzed: iti evamādiḥ

original: na ca tat nirvikāraṃ rūpam itara ālambanāḥ prāpnuvanti iti śakyaṃ vaktum atatkratutvāt teṣām /
analyzed: na ca tat nirvikāram rūpam itara ālambanāḥ prāpnuvanti iti śakyam vaktum a tatkratu tvāt teṣām
translated: And it cannot be said that those who have other objects do not attain that changeless nature of him, because they are not intent on that.

original: ataḥ ca yathā eva dvirūpe parameśvare nirguṇaṃ rūpam anavāpya saguṇa eva avatiṣṭhanta
analyzed: atas ca yathā eva dvirūpe parameśvare nirguṇam rūpam an avāpya sa guṇe eva avatiṣṭhanta
translated: And therefore, just as in the Supreme Lord who has a twofold nature, they abide only in the one with qualities, not attaining the qualityless nature,

original: evaṃ saguṇaḥ api niravagraham aiśvaryam anavāpya sāvagraha eva avatiṣṭhanta iti draṣṭavyam // //
analyzed: evam saguṇaḥ api niravagraham aiśvaryam an avāpya sāvagrahaḥ eva avatiṣṭhantaḥ iti draṣṭavyam  /
translated: so also, even in the one with qualities, they abide only with restrictions, not attaining unrestricted lordship. This is to be seen.

original: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne / / / /
analyzed: darśayataḥ ca evam pratyakṣa anumāne  /
translated: And direct perception and inference show it thus.

original: darśayataḥ ca vikāra āvartitvaṃ parasya jyotiṣaḥ śruti smṛtī /
analyzed: darśayataḥ ca vikāra āvarti tvam parasya jyotiṣaḥ śruti smṛtī
translated: And the Śruti and Smṛti show the revolving of the highest light.

original: 'na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ nemā vidyuto bhānti kuto 'yamagniḥ' kaṭha / / /
analyzed: na tatra sūryaḥ bhāti na candra tārakam na imāḥ vidyutaḥ bhānti kutas yam agniḥ kaṭha
translated: 'There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars, nor these lightnings, much less this fire.' (Kaṭha.🔽Śvetāśvatara.

original: śvetā / / / muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: śvetā muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: Muṇḍaka.)

original: 'na tadbhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅ ko na pāvakaḥ' gī / / iti ca /
analyzed: na tat bhāsayate sūryaḥ na śaśāṅ kaḥ na pāvakaḥ iti ca
translated: 'That is not illuminated by the sun, nor by the moon, nor by fire.' (Gītā.)

original: tat evaṃ vikāra āvartitvaṃ parasya jyotiṣaḥ prasiddham iti abhiprāyaḥ // //
analyzed: tat evam vikāra āvarti tvam parasya jyotiṣaḥ prasiddham iti abhiprāyaḥ  /
translated: The meaning is that it is well known that the Supreme Light undergoes modifications and returns.

original: bhogamātrasāmyaliṅgāc ca / / / /🔽itaḥ ca na niraṅ kuśaṃ vikāra ālambanānām aiśvaryaṃ yasmāt bhogamātram eva eṣām anādisiddhena
analyzed: bhoga mātra sāmya liṅgāt ca  itas ca na vikāra ālambanānām aiśvaryam yasmāt bhoga mātram eva eṣām anādi siddhena
translated: And because of the indication of equality in mere enjoyment.🔽Moreover, the sovereignty of those who depend on modifications is not unrestricted, because it is heard that their enjoyment is equal to that of the eternally existent

original: īśvareṇa samānam iti śrūyate 'tamāhāpo vai khalu mīyante loko 'sau' iti 'sa yathaitāṃ🔽devatāṃ sarvāṇi bhūtānyavantyevaṃ haivaṃvidaṃ sarvāṇi bhūtānyavanti teno etasyai
analyzed: īśvareṇa samānam iti śrūyate tam āha apaḥ vai khalu mīyante iti sa yathā etām  devatām sarvāṇi bhūtāni avanti evam ha evaṃvidam sarvāṇi bhūtāni avanti tena u etasyai
translated: Lord. 'They say that indeed the waters are consumed, that world.' 'Just as all beings depend on that🔽deity, so all beings depend on one who knows thus. Therefore, he attains union with that

original: devatāyai sāyujyaṃ salokatāṃ jayati'bṛ / / /
analyzed: devatāyai sāyujyam salokatām jayatibṛ
translated: deity, co-existence with that deity.'

original: ityādibhedavyapadeśaliṅgebhyaḥ // //
analyzed: ityādi bheda vyapadeśa liṅgebhyaḥ
translated: And because of the indications of distinctions such as these.

original: nanu evaṃ sati sātiśayatvāt antavattvam aiśvaryasya syāt tataḥ ca eṣām āvṛttiḥ prasajyeta ityata uttaraṃ bhagavān bādarāyaṇa ācāryaḥ paṭhati
analyzed: nanu evam sati sātiśaya tvāt antavat tvam aiśvaryasya syāt tatas ca eṣām āvṛttiḥ prasajyeta iti atas uttaram bhagavān bādarāyaṇaḥ ācāryaḥ paṭhati
translated: If that is so, then the sovereignty would have a limit due to having a superior, and from that their return would result. To this, the revered teacher Badarayana replies:

original: anāvṛttiḥ śabdād anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt / / / /
analyzed: anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt
translated: There is no return, because of the word. There is no return, because of the word.

original: nāḍīraśmisamanvitena arcirādiparvaṇā devayānena pathā ye brahmalokaṃ śāstroktaviśeṣaṇaṃ
analyzed: nāḍī raśmi samanvitena arciḥ ādi parvaṇā deva yānena pathā ye brahma lokam śāstra ukta viśeṣaṇam
translated: Those who, by the path of the gods, accompanied by the channels and rays, with the stages of light etc., go to the world of Brahman, which is described by the scriptures,

original: gacchanti yasminnaraśca ha vai ṇyaścārṇavau brahmaloke tṛtīyasyāmito divi yasminnaśvatthaḥ
analyzed: gacchanti yasmin naraḥ ca ha vai ṇyaḥ ca arṇavau brahma loke tṛtīyasyām itas divi yasmin aśvatthaḥ
translated: in which the oceans Nara and Naya are in the world of Brahman, in the third heaven above this, in which the holy fig tree

original: somasavano yasminnaparājitā pūrbrahmaṇo yasmiṃśca prabhuvimitaṃ hiraṇmayaṃ veśma
analyzed: soma savanaḥ yasmin aparājitā pūḥ brahmaṇaḥ yasmin ca prabhu vimitam hiraṇmayam veśma
translated: is the Soma-presser, in which the invincible is in front of Brahman, in which the golden house is measured by the lord,

original: yaścānekadhā mantrārthavādādipradeśeṣu prapañcyate te taṃ prāpya na candralokādivabhuktabhogā āvartante /
analyzed: yaḥ ca anekadhā mantra arthavāda ādi pradeśeṣu prapañcyate te tam prāpya na candra lokāt iva bhukta bhogāḥ āvartante
translated: and which is elaborated in many ways in the sections on mantras, arthavadas etc., having reached that, they do not return like those who have enjoyed pleasures in the moon world etc.

original: kutaḥ /
analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

original: 'tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti' chā / / / / kaṭha / /
analyzed: tayā ūrdhvam āyan amṛta tvam eti chā  kaṭha
translated: Because of statements such as Having gone upwards from those two, one attains immortality (ChU),

original: 'teṣāṃ na punarāvṛttiḥ' bṛ / / /
analyzed: teṣām na punarāvṛttiḥ bṛ
translated: For them there is no return (BrU),

original: 'brahmalokamabhisaṃpadyate' chā / / /
analyzed: brahma lokam abhisaṃpadyate chā
translated: One attains the world of Brahman (ChU),

original: 'na ca punarāvartate' chā / / /
analyzed: na ca punar āvartate chā
translated: And does not return again (ChU),

original: ityādi śabdebhyaḥ /
analyzed: ityādi śabdebhyaḥ
translated: and so on.

original: antavattve api tu aiśvaryasya yathā anāvṛttiḥ tathā varṇitam 'kāryātyaye tadadhyakṣeṇa sahātaḥparam' bra /sū / / / ityatra /
analyzed: antavat tve api tu aiśvaryasya yathā anāvṛttiḥ tathā varṇitam kārya atyaye tad adhyakṣeṇa saha atas param brasū iti atra
translated: Even though the lordship is limited, it is explained how there is no return, as in the passage When the effect is destroyed, along with its presiding deity, beyond that... (Br.S.

original: samyak darśanavidhvasta tamasāṃ tu nityasiddhanirvāṇaparāyaṇānāṃ siddha eva anāvṛttiḥ
analyzed: samyak darśana vidhvasta tamasām tu nitya siddha nirvāṇa parāyaṇānām siddhaḥ eva anāvṛttiḥ
translated: But for those whose darkness has been destroyed by the path of right knowledge, who are devoted to eternal, established nirvana, non-return is indeed established.

original: tadāśrayaṇena eva hi nityasiddhanirvāṇaparāyaṇānāṃ siddhā eva anāvṛttiḥ tadāśrayaṇena
analyzed: tad āśrayaṇena eva hi nitya siddha nirvāṇa parāyaṇānām siddhā eva anāvṛttiḥ tad āśrayaṇena
translated: For it is precisely by relying on that that those who are devoted to eternal, established nirvana have established non-return.

original: eva hi saguṇaśaraṇānām api anāvṛttisiddhiḥ iti /
analyzed: eva hi saguṇa śaraṇānām api anāvṛtti siddhiḥ iti
translated: For it is precisely by relying on that that even those who take refuge in the qualified have established non-return.

original: anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt iti sūtra abhyāsaḥ śāstraparisamāptiṃ dyotayati // //🔽iti śrīmacchārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīmadgovindabhagavatpūjyapādaśiṣyaśrīmacchaṅkarabhagavatpūjyapādakṛtau caturthādhyāyasya
analyzed: anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt anāvṛttiḥ śabdāt iti sūtra abhyāsaḥ śāstra parisamāptim dyotayati  / iti śrīmat śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrīmat govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣya śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat pūjya pāda kṛtau caturtha adhyāyasya
translated: Non-return from the word. Non-return from the word. The repetition of this sutra indicates the completion of the treatise.

original: caturthaḥ pādaḥ // //
analyzed: caturthaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth chapter🔽of the commentary on the Vedanta Sutras, composed by Sri Sankaracharya, the disciple of the venerable Govinda Bhagavat Pujya Pada, the teacher of the great mendicant order of Paramahamsas.

original: samāptamidaṃ brahmasūtraśāṅ karabhāṣyam //
analyzed: samāptam idam brahmasūtra śāṅ kara bhāṣyam
translated: This is the end of the Brahmasutra Shakara Bhashya.
